posts.title: Geometric Linear Algebra
posts.text: VectorsIn physics, the vectors can be arrows in the space. In computer science, the vectors can be ordered list of numbers. Mathematicians consider a more general definition form of vectors. Anything where there is a sensible notion of addition and scalar multiplication can be viewed as vectors. Consider vectors as arrows with its tails sitting at the origin, the coordinates of vectors tells how to get from the tails of vectors to its tip. The addition of vectors is moving along the sum of vectors The scalar multiplication of vectors is scaling the vectors. Consider vectors as ordered lists of numbers, each component of ordered lists of numbers describe how to move parallel to the axes, getting from the tails of vectors to its tip. The addition of vectors is matching up their trems and add each one together. The scalar muliplication of vectors is multiplying each one of their component by that scalar. We usually think of individual vectors as arrows, and think of a set of vectors as points. Linear CombinationsThe linear combination refers to the vector as an operation result of addition and scalar multiplication between multiple vectors. For an arbitrary vector, the vector this coordinate describe is actually the sum of multiple scaled vectors / bases of vectors / unit vectors. The coordinate as scalars describe how each one stretches and squishes vectors / bases of vectors / unit vectors. As a vector, it also has the orginal meaning like the arrow movement or the ordered list of numbers. Any linear combination is relevant to its basis vectors. How to understand linearity? In 2-D linear spaces, fix one of these scalars, and let the other one change its value freely, the tip of resulting vector draws a straight line. The span of vectors refers to what are all the possible vectors we can reach using only these (two) vectors. Linear dependent Whenever we have multiple vectors and we can remove one without reducing the span. One of these vectors could be represented as a linear combination of others, since it is already in the span of the others. Linear independent Each vector add a new dimension to the span. Matrix as Linear TransformationsLinear transformation is a function from a linear space to another linear space. Linear transformation is not called as function because it is to be suggestive of a way to visualize the input-output relation, that is, the movement – move the input vector to output vector. Linear transformation is also called the linear operator, since it can be represented by matrix multiplication, which is an binary operation defined on an algebra. Linear function / Linear funtional refers to a real map which maps a linear space to $\mathbb{R}$. The movement decribed by the linear transformation has two characteristics. All lines must remain lines, without getting curved. The origin remain fixed. The affine transformation is a movement where the origin moves. In other words, the linear transformation keeps grid lines paraller and evenly spaced. Consider taking every possible input vector to some output vector, it is equivalent to consider every point in space move to some other point. How to decribe one of these linear transformations numerically? Only need to record where the (two) basis vectors each land. Consider a linear transformation$$\mathbf{i}=\left[\begin{matrix}1 \\ 0\end{matrix}\right]\to L(\mathbf{i})=\left[\begin{matrix}1 \\ -2\end{matrix}\right]$$ $$\mathbf{j}=\left[\begin{matrix}0 \\ 1\end{matrix}\right]\to L(\mathbf{j})=\left[\begin{matrix}3 \\ 0\end{matrix}\right]$$ Since every vector can be decribed as the sum of scaled bases of vectors. Since the linear transfomation moves the basis vectors, then the vector is the sum of scaled new bases of vectors. let’s write this linear transformation in a linear combination form.$$\left[\begin{matrix}x \\ y\end{matrix}\right]\to L(\left[\begin{matrix}x \\ y\end{matrix}\right])=x\left[\begin{matrix}1 \\ -2\end{matrix}\right]+y\left[\begin{matrix}3 \\ 0\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix}1x+3y \\ -2x+0y\end{matrix}\right]$$Intuitively, we can write it as a matrix multiplication form for convenience$$\left[\begin{matrix}x \\ y\end{matrix}\right]\to L(\left[\begin{matrix}x \\ y\end{matrix}\right])=\left[\begin{matrix}L(\mathbf{i}) & L(\mathbf{j})\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix}x \\ y\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix}1 & 3\\ -2 & 0\end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix}x \\ y\end{matrix}\right]=\left[\begin{matrix}1x+3y \\ -2x+0y\end{matrix}\right]$$In conclusion, linear transformation can be decribed using only the coordinates of where each basis vector lands. Matrices give us a language to describe these transformation where the column represent those coordinates. Any metrix-vector multiplication is just a way to compute what that trnsformation does to a given vector. Every matrix can be interpreted as a certain transformation of space. Matrix Multiplication as CompositionMatrix multiplcation is a compostion of linear transformation. Multipliy two matrices has the geometric meaning of applying one transformation then another. The DeterminantThe linear transformation is accompanied by streching or squishing space. To measure exactly how much are things being scretched is equivalent to measure how much are areas scaled. Similarly, we only need to consider the unit square, take 2-D linear space as an example. The very special scaling vector, by whcih a linear transformation changes any area are called the determinant of a transformation. The determinant of a 2-D transformation is 0, if it squishes all sapce onto a line or even onto a single point. Negative determinant imlies orientation-flipping. Linear Equation SystemsAny linear equation system can be written as the form $\mathbf{Ax}=\mathbf{y}$, it is equivalent to find a vector $\mathbf{x}$ after linear transformation $\mathbf{A}$ lands on $\mathbf{y}$. To solve the linear equation system, we need to find a inverse linear transformation, which is to find the inverse matrix $\mathbf{A}^{-1}$. If the determinant of $\mathbf{A}$ doesn’t equal to 0, then we can find a unique $\mathbf{x}$, which is the unique solution, implying the existence of $\mathbf{A}^{-1}$. If the determinant of $\mathbf{A}$ equal to 0, for a 2-D linear space, it implies this linear transformation squish the whole space into a line, the solution exists iff $\mathbf{y}$ lies on this line. $\mathbf{A}^{-1}$ doesn’t exist if the determinant of $\mathbf{A}$ equal to 0, because we cannot find a inverse linear transformation map a low dimensional space to a high dimensional space, since the linear transformation is a function. For example, we cannot map a point into a line. Let’s review the definition of function: By a function / map $f$ that maps $X$ into $Y$, denoted as $f:X→Y$, we mean a relation $f∈X×Y$ such that For every $x∈X$, there exists a $y∈Y$ such that $xfy$, For every $y,z∈Y$ with $xfy$ and $xfz$, we have $y=z$. The second condition implies we cannot unsquish a linear space. The rank of a matrix is the number of the dimension in the output vector. Since the columns tell us where the basis vector lands after the transformation. The set of all possible outputs of $\mathbf{Ax}$ is the span of column vectors, called the column space of $\mathbf{A}$ Rank is actually the dimension of the column space. $\mathbf{0}$ must lie in the column space since the origin doesn’t change in the linear transformation. For the full rank matrix, only $\mathbf{0}$ in the input space is mapped into $\mathbf{0}$. For the non-full rank matrix, multiple vector lands in $\mathbf{0}$ finally, due to the squishing. These vectors are called the null space or the kernel of the matrix. The null space gives all possible solution to $\mathbf{Ax=0}$ Eigenvectors and EigenvaluesThe eigenvectors refer to vectors which are not knocked off from its span, or still remain in its span after the linear transformation. The eigenvalues refer to how much the eigenvectors being screched or squished after the liner transformation. This can be represented as equations.$$\mathbf{Av}=\lambda\mathbf{v}\Longleftrightarrow(\mathbf{A}-\lambda\mathbf{I})\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{0}$$We are interested in non-zero eigenvectors $\mathbf{v}$, which requires $\mbox{det}(\mathbf{A}-\lambda\mathbf{I})=0$. It means $\mathbf{A}-\lambda\mathbf{I}$ squish non-zero vectors onto $\mathbf{0}$ Otherwise the null space, which is the solution of $(\mathbf{A}-\lambda\mathbf{I})\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{0}$ is unique $\mathbf{0}$. References https://www.3blue1brown.com John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”;

posts.title: Constructing Complex Numbers
posts.text: DefinitionsComplex Numbers: Consider the Cartesian product $\mathbb{R} × \mathbb{R}$ with addition and multiplication defined by$$(a, b) + (c, d) = (a + c, b + d)\(a, b)(c, d) = (ac − bd, bc + ad)$$ The field of complex numbers is the set $\mathbb{C} = \mathbb{R} × \mathbb{R}$ with the operations of addition and multiplication defined above. The additive identity is $(0,0)$ and the multiplicative identity is $(1,0)$. For $(a,b)$ the additive inverse is $(-a,-b)$. If $(a,b)\neq(0,0)$, thhe multiplicative inverse is $(a,b)^{-1}=(\frac{a}{a^2+b^2},\frac{b}{a^2+b^2})$. We denote $z=(a,b)$ by $z=a+bi$ and $\overline{z}=a-bi$. $\mathbb{C}$ is a field. The Abosulute Value of Complex Numbers: If $z=a+bi$ with $a,b∈\mathbb{R}$, the absolute value of $z$ is $|z|=(z\overline{z})^\frac{1}{2} =(a^2+b^2)^\frac{1}{2}$, where, of course, we mean the nonnegative square root in $\mathbb{R}$. If $z,w\in\mathbb{C}$, then $d(z,w)=|z-w|$. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R}^n$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: Constructing Real Numbers
posts.text: DefinitionsUpper Bound, Lower Bound, Bounded: Let $F$ be an ordered field. Let $A$ be a nonempty subset of $F$. $A$ is bounded above if there is an element $M ∈ F$ with the property that if $x ∈ A$, then $x ≤ M$. We call $M$ an upper bound for $A$. $A$ is bounded below if there is an element $m ∈ F$ such that if $x ∈ A$, then $m ≤ x$. We call $m$ a lower bound for $A$. We say that $A$ is bounded if $A$ is bounded above and $A$ is bounded below. Least Upper​ Bound, Greatest Lower Bound: Let $F$ be an ordered field, and let $A$ be a nonempty subset of $F$ which is bounded above. $L ∈ F$ is a least upper bound for $A$ if: $L$ is an upper bound for $A$; if $M$ is any upper bound for $A$, then $L≤M$. The definition of a greatest lower bound is similar with all of the inequalities reversed. The Greatest Lower Bound Property, The Least Upper Bound Property: An ordered field $F$ has the greatest lower bound property if every nonempty subset $A$ of $F$ that is bounded below has a greatest lower bound. That is, there exists an element $l$ of $F$ such that: $l$ is a lower bound for $A$; if $m$ is any lower bound for $A$ , then $m≤l$. The definition of the least upper bound property is similar. Real Numbers, $\mathbb{R}$ / Complete Ordered Field: The real numbers are the unique, up to order isomorphism ordered field that satisfies the least upper bound property. We will denote this field by $\mathbb{R}$. $\mathbb{R}$ is obtained from $\mathbb{Q}$ by filling the “holes” in $\mathbb{Q}$ to obtain an ordered field that satisfies the Completeness Axiom. We thus say that $\mathbb{R}$ is a complete ordered field. $\mathbf{R}$, Equivalence Classes in $\mathcal{C}$: Let $(a_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$, and $(b_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$ be Cauchy sequences in $\mathbb{Q}$. $(a_k){k∈\mathbb{N}}$ is equivalent to $(b_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$, denoted by $(a_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}} ∼ (b_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$, if $(c_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}= (a_k − b_k){k∈\mathbb{N}}$ is in $\mathcal{I}$. The set $\mathcal{I}$ consists of Cauchy sequences that converge to 0. $∼$ defines an equivalence relation on $\mathcal{C}$. The set $\mathcal{C}$ denote the set of all Cauchy sequences of rational numbers. $\mathbf{R}$ is defined as the set of equivalence classes in $\mathcal{C}$. The equivalent class of $(a_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$ is denoted by $[a_k]$. Order Relation on $\mathbf{R}$: Let $a = [a_k]$, $b = [b_k]$ be distinct elements of $\mathbf{R}$. We define $a < b$ if $a_k < b_k$ eventually and $b < a$ if $b_k < a_k$ eventually, which is an order relation on $\mathbf{R}$. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R^n}$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: Countability
posts.text: DefinitionsCountably Infinite, Countable, Uncountable: A set $X$ is called countably infinite if there exists a bijection $f$ that maps $X$ onto the set $\mathbb{N} $ of natural numbers. $X$ is called countable if it is either finite or countably infinite. $X$ is called uncountable if it is not countable. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 1: Every subset of a countable set is countable. Proposition 2: A countable union of countable sets is countable. Corollary 1: (Cantor) $\mathbb{Q} $ is countable. Proposition 4: (Cantor) $\mathbb{R} $ is uncountable. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R}^n$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: Elements of Set Theory
posts.text:
DefinitionsSubset, Proper Subset: If every member of $A$ is also a member of $B$, then $A$ is a subset of $B$ and write $A⊆B$. $ A=B$ holds iff both $A⊆B$ and $B⊆A$ hold. If $A⊆B$ but $A
eq B$, then $A$ is a proper subset of $B$, and write $A ⊂ B$。 Finite, Cardinality, Singleton, Infite: For any set $S$ that contains finitely many elements (in which case we say $S$ is finite), we denote by $|S|$ the total number of elements that $ S$ contains, and refer to this number as the cardinality of $S$. $S$ is a singleton if $|S| = 1$. If $S$ contains infinitely many elements (in which case we say $S$ is infinite), then we write $|S| = ∞$. Empty Set: The set that contains no elements is defined as an empty set, that is,$$∅ := {x : x 
eq x},$$ We have $∅ ⊆ S$ for any set $S$, it implies that $∅$ is unique. If $S 
eq ∅$, we say that $S$ is nonempty. ${∅}$ is a nonempty set. Power Set: We define the class of all subsets of a given set $S$ as $$2^S :={T :T ⊆S},$$ which is called the power set of $S$. Union, Intersection, Difference: Given any two sets $A$ and $B$, The union of $A$ and $B$, denoted as $A ∪ B$, is defined as the set ${x : x ∈ A\ \mbox{or} \ x ∈ B}$. The intersection of $A$ and $B$, denoted as $A ∩ B$, is defined as the set ${x : x ∈ A\ \mbox{and}\ x ∈ B}$. If $A ∩ B = ∅$, we say that $A$ and $B$ are disjoint. If $A ⊆ B$, then $A∪B = B$ and $A∩B = A$. $∅ ∪ S = S$ and $∅ ∩ S = ∅$ for any set $S$. The difference between $A$ and $B$, denoted as $A\setminus B$, is defined as the set ${ x : x ∈ A\ \mbox{and}\ x ∈/ B } $. Class, Family, Member: “Class” or “family” refer to a nonempty collection of sets. If $\mathcal{A}$ is a class, then $\mathcal{A} 
eq ∅$ and any member $A ∈ \mathcal{A}$ is a set. The union of all members of this class, $ igcup \mathcal{A}$, $ igcup_{A∈\mathcal{A}}A$, is defined as the set ${x : x ∈ A\ \mbox{for some}\ A ∈ \mathcal{A}}$. To specify a class $\mathcal{A}$, we can designate a set $I$ as a set of indices If $I={k,k+1,\dots, K}$ for some integers $k$ and $K$ with $k<K$, then we often write $ igcup^K A_i$, $ igcup_{i=k}^KA_i$ for $ igcup_{i\in I}A_i$. If $I={k,k+1,\dots,}$ for some integer $k$, then we may write $ igcup^\infty A_i$, $ igcup_{i=k}^\infty A_i$ for $ igcup_{i\in I}A_i$ The intersection of all sets in $\mathcal{A}$, $ igcap \mathcal{A}$ , $ igcap_{A∈\mathcal{A}}A$, is defined as the set ${x : x ∈ A\ \mbox{for each}\ A ∈ \mathcal{A}}$. Ordered Pair: An **ordered pair **is an ordered list $(a,b)$ consisting of two objects $a$ and $ b$. (Cartesian) Product: The (Cartesian) product of $n$ sets $A_1, …, A_n$, is then defined as $$A_1 ×···×A_n :={(a_1,…,a_n):a_i∈A_i, i=1,…,n}.$$ (Binary) Relation: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two nonempty sets. A subset $R$ of $X × Y$ is called a (binary) relation from $X$ to $Y$. Reflexive, Transitive, Symmetric, Antisymmetric, Complete: A relation $R$ on a nonempty set $X$ is said to be reflexive if $xRx$ for each $x ∈ X$ **transitive **if $xRy$ and $yRz$ imply $xRz$ for any $x,y,z ∈ X.$ **symmetric **if, for any $x, y ∈ X$, $xRy$ implies $yRx$, antisymmetric if, for any $x, y ∈ X$, $xRy$ and $yRx$ imply $x = y$. complete if either $xRy$ or $yRx$ holds for each $x,y ∈ X$. Equivalence Relation, Equivalence Class: A relation $∼$ on a nonempty set $X$ is called an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric and transitive. For any $x ∈ X$, the equivalence class of $x$ relative to $∼$ is defined as the set$$[x]_∼ :={y∈X:y∼x}.$$ Let $X$ be a set. An equivalence relation on $X$ is a relation $R$ on $X$ such that (Reflexive) For all $x ∈ X$, $x ∼ x$. (Symmetric) For $x,y∈X$, if $x∼y$ then $y∼x$. (Transitive) For $s,y,z∈X$, if $x∼y$ and $y∼z$, then $x∼z$. Preorder, Partial order, Linear order: A relation $\succsim$ on a nonempty set $X$ is called a **preorder **on $X$ if it is transitive and reflexive. $\succsim$ is said to be a **partial order **on $X$ if it is an antisymmetric preorder on $X$. $\succsim$ is called a **linear order **on $X$ if it is a partial order on $X$ which is complete. By a preordered set we mean a list $(X, \succsim)$ where $X$ is a nonempty set and $\succsim$ is a preorder on $X$. If $\succsim$ is a partial order on $X$, then $(X, \succsim)$ is called a poset (short for partially ordered set) If $\succsim$ is a linear order on $X$, then $(X, \succsim)$ is called either a chain or a loset (short for linearly ordered set). Function / Map: By a function / map $f$ that maps $X$ into $Y$, denoted as $f:X→Y$, we mean a relation $f∈X×Y$ such that For every $x∈X$, there exists a $y∈Y$ such that $xfy$, For every $y,z∈Y$ with $xfy$ and $xfz$, we have $y=z$. $X$ is the domain of $f$ and $Y$ the codomain of $f$. The range of $f$ is$$f(X):={y∈Y :xfy\ \mbox{for some}\ x∈X}.$$ The set of all functions that map $X$ into $Y$ is denoted by $Y^X$ or $f : X → Y$ . When $ f(x) = y$, we refer to $y$ as the image or value of $x$ under $f$. Composition: Given functions $f : X → Z$ and $g : Z → Y$, The composition of $f$ and $g$ is the function $g◦f : X → Y$, where $g◦f(x) := g(f(x))$. $(g ◦ f )(x)$ is usually written as $g ◦ f (x$). Surjection, Injection, Bijection: If its range equals its codomain, that is, if $f(X) = Y$, then one says that $f$ maps $X$ onto $Y$, and refers to it as a surjection. If $f$ maps distinct points in its domain to distinct points in its codomain, that is, if $x
eq y$ implies $f(x) 
eq f(y)$ for all $x,y ∈ X$, then we say that $f$ is an injection. If $f$ is both injective and surjective, then it is called a bijection. Self-map, Identity Function: A function whose domain and codomain are identical, that is, a function in $X^X$, is called a self-map on $X$. The identity function is a self-map on $X$, denoted as $\mbox{id}_X$, and defined as $\mbox{id}_X (x) := x$ for all $x ∈ X$. $\mbox{id}_X$ is a bijection. Binary Operation: Let $X$ be any nonempty set. We refer to a function of the form $• : X ×X → X$ as a binary operation on $X$, and write $x•y$ instead of $•(x,y)$ for any $x, y ∈ X$. Field: Let $X$ be any nonempty set, let $+$ and $·$ be two binary operations on $X$. The list $(X, +, ·)$ is called a field if the following properties are satisfied: (Closure) $x+y\in X$ and $xy\in X$ for all $x,y∈X$; (Commutativity) $x+y=y+x$ and $xy=yx$ for all $x,y∈X$; (Associativity) $(x+y)+z = x+(y+z)$ and $(xy)z = x(yz)$ for all $x,y,z ∈ X$; (Existence of Identity Elements) There exist elements $0$ and $1$ in $X$ such that $0 + x = x = x + 0$ and $1x = x = x1$ for all $x ∈ X$; (Existence of Inverse Elements) (the additive inverse of $x$) For each $x ∈ X$, there exists an element $−x$ in $X$ such that $x+−x = 0 = −x+x$, and (the multiplicative inverse of $x$) For each $x ∈ X ackslash{0}$, there exists an element $x^{−1}$ in $X$ such that $xx^{−1} = 1 = x^{−1}x$. (Distributivity) $x(y + z) = xy + xz$ for all $x, y, z ∈ X$; (Cancellation) If $xz=yz$ and $z
eq0$ then $x=y$ for all $x,y,z ∈ X$; A field without the multiplicative inverse of $x$ and cancellation rule for the multiplication is a commutative ring with 1. Ordered Field: The list $(X,+,·,≥)$ is called an ordered field if $(X,+,·)$ is a field, and if $≥$ is a partial order on $X$ such that (Addition) If $x,y,z\in X$, and $x\leq y$, then $x+z\leq y+z$ (Multiplication by nonnegative elements) If $x,y,z\in X$, and $x\leq y,\ 0\leq z$ then $xz\leq yz$ The list $(X,+,·,<)$ is called an **ordered field** if $(X,+,·)$ is a field, and if $<$ is a relation on $X$ such that (Trichotomy) If $x,y\in X$, then $x<y,\ x=y$ or $x>y$ (Transitivity) If $x,y\in X$, and $x<y,\ y<z$, then $x<z$ (Addition) If $x,y,z\in X$, and $x<y$, then $x+z<y+z$ (Multiplication by postive elements) If $x,y,z\in X$, and $x<y,\ 0<z$ then $xz<yz$ We adopt the following notation: $$X_+ :={x∈X :x≥0}\ and\ X_{++} :={x∈X :x>0},$$ $$X_− :={x∈X :x≤0}\ and\ X_{−−} :={x∈X :x<0}.$$ Absolute Value, The Triangle Inequality: Let $(X, +, ·, ≥)$ be an ordered field. The function $|·| : X → X$ defined by $$|x|:=\left{ egin{matrix}x,&if\ x\geq0\-x,\ &if\ x <0\end{matrix}ight.$$ is called the absolute value function. The following is called the triangle inequality: $$|x+y|≤|x|+|y|\ \ \ for\ all\ x,y∈X.$$ It is valid within any ordered field. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 2: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two nonempty sets. A function $f ∈ Y^X$ is invertible if, and only if, it is a bijection. Proposition 3: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two nonempty sets. A function $f ∈ Y^X$ is invertible if, and only if, there exists a function $g∈X^Y$ such that $g◦f=\mbox{id}_X$ and $f◦g=\mbox{id}_Y$. Proposition 6: (The Archimedean Property) For any $(a, b) ∈ \mathbb{R}_{++} × \mathbb{R}$, there exists an $m ∈\mathbb{N}$ such that $b < ma$. For any $a, b ∈ \mathbb{R}$ such that $a < b$, there exists a $q ∈\mathbb{Q}$ such that $a < q < b$. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R^n}$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: Elements of Metric Spaces
posts.text: A function $f$ on $\mathbb{R}$ is continuous at a given point $a ∈ \mathbb{R}$ iff the image of a point which is close to $a$ is itself close to $f(a)$. The “geometric” way of thinking about continuity depends intrinsically on the “distance” between two points. For the continuity of functions defined on more complicated sets, the meaning of the term “close” is not transparent. Therefore, need the conception of distance between two elements of an arbitrary set By way of abstraction, the notion of distance function is built only on three properties. These properties are strong enough to introduce to an arbitrary nonempty set a geometry rich enough to build a satisfactory theory of continuous functions. DefinitionsMetric: Let $X$ be any nonempty set. Let $X$ be any nonempty set. A function $d : X × X → \mathbb{R}_+$ that satisfies the following properties is called a distance function or a metric on $X$: For any $x, y, z ∈ X$, (Positive Definite) $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$, (Symmetry) $d(x, y)=d(y, x)$, (Triangle Inequality) $d(x, y) ≤ d(x, z) + d(z, y)$. Metric Space: If $d$ is a distance function on $X$, we say that $(X, d)$ is a metric space, and refer to the elements of $X$ as points in $(X, d)$. Metric Subspace: If $(X,d)$ is a metric space and $∅\neq Y ⊂X$. $(Y, d|_{Y ×Y} )$, or simply $Y$, is a metric subspace of $X$ $d$ is called the inherited metric. Sequence: A sequence in a nonempty set $X$ is a function $f : \mathbb{N }→ X$, This function is represented as $(x_1,x_2,…)$ where $x_i := f(i)$ for each $i ∈ \mathbb{N}$. The set of all sequences in $X$ is $X^{\mathbb{N}}$ or $X^∞$. Subsequence: A subsequence of a sequence $f ∈ X^\mathbb{N}$ is a function of the form $f ◦σ$ where $σ :\mathbb{N} → \mathbb{N}$ is strictly increasing That is, $σ(k) < σ(l)$ for any $k,l ∈ N$ with $k < l$. This function is represented as the array $(x_{m_1},x_{m_2},…)$ with $m_k = σ(k)$ and $x_{m_k} = f(m_k)$ for each $k = 1,2,….$ Increasing, Decreasing, Monotonic: A real sequence $(x_m)$ is said to be increasing if $x_m ≤ x_{m+1}$ for each $m ∈\mathbb{N}$, and strictly increasing if $x_m < x_{m+1}$ for each $m ∈\mathbb{N}$. It is said to be (strictly) decreasing if $(−x_m)$ is (strictly) increasing. A real sequence which is either increasing or decreasing is referred to as a monotonic sequence. Convergent Sequence: A sequence $(a_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ of points is a convergent sequence in a metric spaces $X$ if, given any real number $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N_\varepsilon\in\mathbb{N}$ such that if $n \geq N_\varepsilon$, then $d(a_n, L) < \varepsilon$. $L$ is called the sequitial limit. Cauchy Sequence: A sequence $(a_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ of real numbers is a Cauchy sequence in a metric spaces $X$ if, given any real number $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists an integer $N_\varepsilon\in\mathbb{N}$ such that if $n, m \geq N_\varepsilon$, then $d(a_n, a_m) < \varepsilon$. Intuitively speaking, by a Cauchy sequence we mean a sequence the terms of which eventually get arbitrarily close to one another. Subsequential Limit: Given any $(x_m) ∈ \mathbb{R}^∞$, we say that $x ∈ \overline{\mathbb{R}} $ is a subsequential limit of $(x_m)$ if there exists a subsequence $(x_{m_k} )$ with $x_{m_k} → x$ as $k → ∞$ That is, if, for any $ε>0$, there exists a $K∈\mathbb{N} $ such that $ |x_m −x|<ε$ for all $k≥K$. Limit Supremum, Limit Infimum: Let $(a_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$ be a bounded sequence of real numbers. For each $n ∈ \mathbb{N}$, define $b_n = \sup{a_k | k ≥ n}$, and $c_n = \inf{a_k | k ≥ n}$. We define the limit supremum of the sequence $(a_k){k∈\mathbb{N}}$ to be $\lim{n→∞} b_n$, and we denote this by $\lim \sup_{k→∞} a_k$. We define the limit infimum of $(a_k){k∈\mathbb{N}}$ similarly: $\lim \inf{k→∞} a_k = \lim_{n→∞} c_n$. Propositions and TheoremsYoung’s Inequality: Suppose $a,b\geq 0$ in $\mathbb{R}$. Suppose $p,q\in \mathbb{R}$ with $p,q>1$ such that $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q} = 1$. Then$$ab\leq\frac{a^p}{p}+\frac{b^q}{q}$$ Theorem 3.2.7: (Hölder’s Inequality) Suppose $x = (x_1,x_2,…,x_n) ∈ \mathbb{R}^n$ and $y = (y_1,y_2,…,y_n) ∈ \mathbb{R}^n$ Suppose $p,q\in \mathbb{R}$ with $p,q>1$ such that $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q} = 1$. Then$$\sum^n_{k=1}|x_k-y_k|\leq(\sum^n_{k=1}|x_k|^p)^\frac{1}{p}(\sum^n_{k=1}|y_k|^q)^\frac{1}{q}$$ Minkowski’s Inequality 1: For any $n ∈ \mathbb{R} $, $a_i,b_i ∈\mathbb{R}, i = 1,…,n$, and any $1 ≤ p <∞$, $$ \left(\sum^n_{i=1}|a_i +b_i|^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}\leq\left(\sum^n_{i=1}|a_i |^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}+\left(\sum^n_{i=1}|b_i|^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}$$ Minkowski’s Inequality 2: For any $(x_m),(y_m) ∈ \mathbb{R}^\infty $, and $1\leq p<\infty $, $$\left(\sum^n_{i=1}|x_i +y_i|^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}\leq\left(\sum^n_{i=1}|x_i |^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}+\left(\sum^n_{i=1}|y_i|^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}$$ Examples and ExercisesDiscrete Metric Space: Let $X$ be any nonempty set and, for $x_1,x_2 ∈ X$, define$$d(x_1,x_2)=\left{\begin{matrix}0&if\ x_1=x_2\ 1& if\ x_1\neq x_2\end{matrix}\right.$$ This is called the discrete metric, the pair $(X,d)$ is referred to as a discrete metric space. It is designed to disabuse people of the notion that every metric looks like the usual metric on $\mathbb{R}^n$. The discrete metric is very handy for producing counterexamples. $(\mathbb{R}^n, d_p) =\mathbb{R}^{n,p}=\ell^p_n(\mathbb{R})$ For each $1≤p≤∞$, where $d_p :\mathbb{R}^n×\mathbb{R}^n →\mathbb{R}+$ is defined by$$d_p(x, y) := |x-y|_p=\left(\sum^n{i=1}|x_i − y_i|^p \right)^{\frac1{p}}\ \ \ \ \mbox{for}\ \ 1 ≤ p < ∞,$$ and $$d_p(x,y):=\max{|x_i −y_i|:i=1,…,n}\ \ \ \ \mbox{for}\ \ p=∞.$$ $(\mathbb{R}^n, d_p)$ is not a metric space for $p < 1$. $(\ell^p, d_p)$: For any $1 ≤ p < ∞$, we define$$\ell^p :={(x_m)∈\mathbb{R}^∞ : \sum^∞_{i=1} |x_i|^p <∞}.$$ and $d_p : \ell^p × \ell^p → \mathbb{R} _+$ is defined by$$d_p ((x_m) , (y_m)) := \left(\sum^\infty_{i=1}|x_i − y_i|^p\right)^\frac1{p} .$$ Any $\ell^p$ space is smaller than the set of all real sequences $\mathbb{R}^∞$ since the members of such a space are real sequences that are either bounded or that satisfy some form of a summability condition (that ensures that $d_p$ is real-valued). Indeed, no $d_p$ defines a distance function on the entire $\mathbb{R}^∞$. $(\ell^\infty, d_\infty)$: $\ell^∞$ is the set of all bounded real sequences,$$\ell^∞ :={(x_m)∈\mathbb{R}^∞ :\sup{|x_m|:m∈\mathbb{N}}<∞}.$$ and $d_∞ : \ell^∞ ×\ell^∞ → \mathbb{R} _+$ is defined by $$d_∞ ((x_m) , (y_m)) := |x_m − y_m|_∞=\sup{|x_m − y_m| : m ∈ \mathbb{N}}.$$ This metric is called the sup-metric on the set of all bounded real sequences. $(\mathbf{B}(T), d_\infty)$: Let $T$ be any nonempty set. $\mathbf{B}(T)$ is the set of all bounded real functions defined on $T$,$$\mathbf{B}(T):={f ∈\mathbb{R}^T :\sup{|f(x)|:x∈T}<∞}.$$ and $d_∞ : \mathbf{B}(T) ×\mathbf{B}(T ) → \mathbb{R}_+$ is defined by$$d_∞ (f, g) := |f − g|_∞=\sup{|f (x) − g(x)| : x ∈ T }.$$ An $n$-vector or a sequence can always be thought of as special functions $\mathbf{B}({1, …, n})$ coincides with $\mathbb{R}^{n,∞}$ (for any $n ∈ \mathbb{N}$) $\mathbf{B}(\mathbb{N})$ coincides with $\ell^∞$. Every continuous function on $[a, b]$ is bounded, and hence $\mathbf{C}[a, b] ⊆\mathbf{B}[a, b]$. Consequently, we can consider $\mathbf{C}[a, b]$ as a metric subspace of $\mathbf{B}[a, b]$. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R^n}$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: Compactness
posts.text: The power of compactness: providing a finite structure for infinite sets. In many problems where finiteness makes life easier (such as in optimization problems), compactness does the same thing. DefinitionsCover, Open Cover: Let $X$ be a metric space and $S ⊆ X$. A class $\mathcal{O}$ of subsets of $X$ is said to cover $S$ if $S⊆\cup\mathcal{O}$. If all members of $\mathcal{O}$ are open in $X$, then we say that $\mathcal{O}$ is an open cover of $S$. Compact: A metric space $X$ is said to be compact if every open cover of $X$ has a finite subset that also covers $X$. A subset $S$ of $X$ is said to be compact in $X$ if every open cover of $S$ has a finite subset that also covers $S$. If $S$ is a compact subset of a metric space $Y$, and $Y$ is a metric subspace of $X$, then $S$ is compact in $X$. $(0, 1)$ is not a compact subset of $\mathbb{R} $ (or that $(0, 1)$ is not a compact metric space). A finite subset of any metric space is necessarily compact. Much less trivially, $[0,1]$ is a compact subset of $\mathbb{R} $. Sequentially Compact: A subset $S$ of a metric space $X$ is sequentially compact iff, every sequence in $S$ has a subsequence that converges to a point in $S$. Since the closedness property can be characterized in terms of convergent se- quences (Proposition 1). Given that every compact space is closed, it makes sense to ask if it is possible to characterize compactness in the same terms as well. So it comes to the sequentially compactness. Sequentially compactness is a stronger condition than closedness. If a subset is sequentially compact, then it is closed. Sequentially compactness is a stronger condition than completeness. If a subset is sequentially compact, then it is complete. Totally Bounded, Precompact: A set $S$ in a metric space $X$ totally bounded (or precompact) if, for any $ε > 0$, there exists a finite subset $T$ of $S$ such that $S ⊆ {N_{ε,X}(x) : x ∈ T}$. This property is strictly more demanding than boundedness. Every totally bounded subset of a metric space is bounded. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 4: Any closed subset of a compact metric space $X$ is compact. Theorem 3.6.4 / Proposition 5: Any compact subset of a metric space $X$ is closed and bounded. Compactness is, in general, a stronger property than closedness and boundedness put together; it often introduces significantly more structure to the analysis. Corollary 3.6.5 If $A$ is a compact set in a metric space $X$, then every infinite subset of $A$ has an accumulation point in $A$. Corollary 3.6.6 Let $A$ be a compact set in a metric space. Then, every infinite sequence in $A$ has a subsequence that converges to a point in $A$. Corollary 3.6.5 is equivalent to corollary 3.6.6. Lemma 1: Every sequentially compact subset of a metric space $X$ is totally bounded. Lemma 3.6.16: Let $X$ be a metric space. If $A ⊂ X$ has the property that every infinite subset of $A$ has an accumulation point in $X$, then there exists a countable collection of open sets ${U_i | i ∈ \mathbb{N}}$ such that, if $V$ is any open set in $X$ and $x ∈ A ∩ V$ , then there is some $U_i$ such that $x ∈ U_i ⊂ V$ . Lemma 2: Let $X$ be a metric space. If $A ⊂ X$ has the property that every infinite subset of $A$ has an accumulation point in $X$, then for every open cover of $A$, there is a finite subcover. Let $S$ be a sequentially compact subset of a metric space $X$, and $\mathcal{O}$ an open cover of $S$. Then there exists an $ε>0$ such that, for any $x∈S$, we can find an $O_x ∈\mathcal{O}$ with $N_{ε,X}(x) ⊆ O_x$. Theorem 3.6.19 / Theorem 2: A subset $S$ of a metric space $X$ is compact iff it is sequentially compact. The properties of compactness and sequential compactness are equivalent for any given metric space. The Heine-Borel Theorem: For any $−∞ < a < b < ∞$, the $n$-dimensional cube $[a,b]^n$ is compact. Theorem 3.6.21 / Theorem 1: Given any $n ∈ \mathbb{N} $, a subset of $\mathbb{R}^n$ is compact iff, it is closed and bounded. Examples and ExercisesExercise 3.6.8: A finite subset of any metric space is necessarily compact. Example: $(0, 1)$ is not a compact subset of $\mathbb{R} $. $(0, 1)$ is not a compact metric space. $[0,1]$ is a compact subset of $\mathbb{R} $. $\mathbb{R} $ is obviously not compact. $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$ is sequentially compact, and hence, compact. Example: The empty set is compact in any metric space. Exercise 3.6.8: The intersection of two compact sets is compact. A finite union of compact sets is compact. A countable union of compact sets does not need to be compact. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. posts.text:
Connectedness, gives one a glimpse of how one would study the geometry of an arbitrary metric space. Intuitively speaking, a connected subset of a metric space is one that cannot be partitioned into two (or more) separate pieces, it is rather in one whole piece. DefinitionsConnected: A metric space $X$ is connected if there do not exist two nonempty and disjoint open subsets $O$ and $U$ of $X$ such that $ O ∪ U = X$. A subset $S ⊆ X$ is connected in $X$ iff it cannot be written as a disjoint union of two nonempty sets that are open in $S$. Disconnected: Let $X$ be a metric space and $A ⊂ X$. $A$ is disconnected if there exist open sets $U, V ⊂ X$ such that $ U∩A

To show disconnected, find a good pair of sets. To show connected, check every potential pair of sets. Connected Component, Totally Disconnected: If $X$ is a metric space and $x_0\in X$ The connected component of $x_0$ in $X$ is the union of the connected sets that contain $x_0$. A metric space $X$ is totally disconnected if the connected component of each point is the point itself. Discrete metric spaces only have isolated points, if its cardinality is 2, then take two points $a,\ b$, and consider $B_\varepsilon(a),\ B_\varepsilon(b)$, where $\varepsilon<1$. According to the proposition 2, a discrete space is not connected unless it contains only one element, because any subset of the discrete space is clopen. Exercise 3.6.35: A finite subset of any metric space is connected iff its cardinality is at most 1. If its cardinality is 2, then take two points $a,\ b$, and consider $B_\varepsilon(a),\ B_\varepsilon(b)$, where $\varepsilon= rac{d(a,b)}{2}$ or $\varepsilon= rac{d(a,b)}{3}$. A subset $A$ of $\mathbb{R}$ in the usual metric is connected iff $A$ is an interval. Proof We first prove that any interval $I$ is connected in $\mathbb{R}$. Exercise 3.6.35: A convex subset of $\mathbb{R}^n$ with the usual metric is a connected set. Proof: Assume that a convex set $A⊂\mathbb{R}^n$ is disconnected. Then for some open sets $O,U$, we have $O∪U=A$. Consider some $o∈O$ and $u∈U$. Define $L$ as the line segment connecting $u$ and $v$. Thus, $u∈O∩L≠∅$ and $v∈U∩L≠∅$. Since $A$ is convex, $L⊂A$. Then $(O∩L)∩(V∩L)⊂O∩U=∅$, so $(O∩L)∩(U∩L)=∅$. Furthermore, $(O∪U)∩L=A∩L=L$, so $(O∩L)∪(U∩L)=L$. As a metric subspace $L$ is open, since $O,\ U$ are both open, so $O∩L, U∩L$ are nonempty disjoint open sets. Thus, $L$ is disconnected. Or assume that a convex set $A⊂\mathbb{R}^n$ is disconnected. Thus, $u∈U∩L≠∅$ and $v∈V∩L≠∅$. Since $A$ is convex, $L⊂A$. Then $(U∩L)∩(V∩L)⊂(U∩A)∩(V∩A)=∅$, so $(U∩L)∩(V∩L)=∅$. Furthermore, $((U∩A)∪(V∩A))∩L=A∩L=L$, so $((U∩A)∩L)∪((V∩A)∩L)=(U∩L)∪(V∩L)=L$. Let $\varepsilon>0$ and let $a∈\mathbb{R}$. Choose $δ= rac{\varepsilon}{||v−u||}$ which is greater than 0. Then if $|t−a|<δ$, we have $$  egin{aligned}||f(t)−f(a)||&=||(1−t)u+tv−(1−a)u−av||\&=||(a−t)u+(t−a)v||\&=||(t−a)v−(t−a)u||\&=|t−a|⋅||v−u||\&<δ||v−u||\&= rac{\varepsilon}{||v−u||}||v−u||\&=\varepsilon \end{aligned}$$ Thus, $f$ is continuous at $a$. Since $a$ was arbitrary, $f$ is continuous. Since $[0,1]$ is an interval, it is connected. Thus, since $f$ is continuous and $f([0,1])=L$, $L$ is connected. Contradiction. posts.title: Separability
posts.text: Separability, identifies those metric spaces that have relatively “few” open sets. Intuitively speaking, one may think of a separable metric space as a space which is “not very large.” After all, in such a space, there is a countable set which is “almost” equal to the entire space. DefinitionsDense, Separable: Let $X$ be a metric space and $Y ⊆ X$. If $cl_X(Y) = X$, then $Y$ is said to be dense in $X$ . $X$ is said to be separable if it contains a countable dense set. A set $Y ⊆ X$ is dense in a metric space $X$ iff, any point in $X$ can be approached by means of a sequence that is contained entirely in $Y$. So, $X$ is a separable metric space iff, it contains a countable set $Y$ such that $x ∈ X$ iff there exists a $(y_m) ∈ Y^∞$ with $y_m → x$ This is also equivelant to say $Y\subseteq X$ and $X$ contains all the accumulation points of $Y$. In any metric space $X$, $X$ is dense in $X$. Propositions and TheoremsExample 6: Any metric subspace of a separable metric space is separable. Theorem 3.6.29: If $(X, d)$ is a compact metric space, then $X$ is separable. Proof: For each $n ∈ \mathbb{N}$, consider the collection of open balls $\mathcal{O}={B_{\frac{1}{n}}(x) | x ∈ X}$. This is an open covering of $X$, and hence, there is a finite subcovering $\mathcal{U}$. Set $X_n={x\in X:B_{\frac{1}{n}}(x)\in \mathcal{U}}$, and define $S=\cup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}X_n$, then we claim that $S$ is dense in $X$. Since $\overline{S}\subseteq X$, we need to prove $X\subseteq \overline{S}$. Take any $x\in X,\ x\notin S$, there is $y\in S$ such that $x\in B_r(y)$. Prove that $x$ is the accumulation point of $S$ by showing that $y\in {B_r(y)\setminus {y}}\cap S$. The Weierstrass Approximation Theorem: The set of all polynomials defined on $[a, b]$ is dense in $\mathbf{C}[a, b]$. That is,$$cl_{\mathbf{C}[a,b]}(\mathbf{P}[a, b]) = \mathbf{C}[a, b].$$ Proposition 3: Let $X$ be metric space. If $X$ is separable, then there exists a countable class $\mathcal{O}$ of open subsets $X$ such that $$U= {O∈\mathcal{O}:O⊆U}$$ for any open subset $U$ of $X$ One major reason for why separable metric spaces areseful is that in such spaces all open sets can be described in terms of a countable set of open sets. Keep in mind that many interesting properties of a metric space are defined through the notion of an open set. For instance, if we know all the open subsets of a metric space, then we know all the closed and/or connected sets in this space. Similarly, if we know all the open subsets of a metric space, then we know which sequences in this space are convergent and which ones are not. Consequently, a lot can be learned about the general structure of a metric space by studying the class of all open subsets of this space. But the significance of this observation would be limited, if, in a sense, we had “too many” open sets lying around. In the case of a separable metric space this is not the case, for such a space has only a countable number of open sets “that matter” in the sense that all other open subsets of this space can be described using only these (countably many) open sets. This is the gist of Proposition 3. Examples and ExercisesExercise 3.6.26, Example 6: The only dense subset of $X$ is $X$ itself iff, $X$ is a discrete metric space. A discrete space is separable iff it is countable. Example 3.6.25, Example 6: $\mathbb{R}^{n,p}$ is separable for any $1 ≤ p ≤ ∞$. $\mathbb{Q}^n$ is dense in $\mathbb{R}^n$ in the usual metric. The “dyadic numbers,” that is, the set $D = {\frac{a}{2^n}∈\mathbb{Q}|a,n ∈ \mathbb{Z}}$, are also dense in $\mathbb{R}$ in the usual metric. Example 6: $\ell_p$ is separable for any $1≤p<∞$. Example 6: $\mathbf{C}[a, b]$ is separable for any $−∞ < a ≤ b < ∞$. A corollary of the Weierstrass Approximation Theorem Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. posts.title: Completeness
posts.text: DefinitionsComplete: A metric space $X$ is said to be complete if every Cauchy sequence in $X$ converges to a point in $X$. Completeness is a stronger condition than closedness in a metric subspace. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 6: Let $(x^m)$ be a sequence in a metric space $X$. If $(x^m)$ is convergent, then it is Cauchy. If $(x^m)$ is Cauchy, then ${x_1,x_2,…}$ is bounded, but $(x_m)$ need not converge in $X$. If $(x^m)$ is Cauchy and has a subsequence that converges in $X$, then it converges in $X$ as well. Proposition 7: Let $X$ be a metric space, and $Y$ a metric subspace of $X$. If $Y$ is complete, then it is closed in $X$. If $Y$ is closed in $X$ and $X$ is complete, then $Y$ is complete. Corollary 1: A metric subspace of a complete metric space $X$ is complete iff, it is closed in $X$. **Theorem 1.1.6, Theorem 1.1.8 **: (The Least Upper Bound Property in $\mathbb{R}$, The Completeness Axiom) Every nonempty subset in $\mathbb{R}$ that is bounded above has a least upper bound. This can be viewed as a definition or an axiom. Lemma 1.6.13: Every sequence in $\mathbb{R}$ has a monotonic subsequence. Due to the infinitiness of sequences. Lemma 1.6.14: (Monotone Convergence Theorem in $\mathbb{R}$) Every bounded monotonic sequence in $\mathbb{R}$ converges to an element in $\mathbb{R}$. The Cantor-Fréchet Intersection Theorem: A metric space $X$ is complete iff, for any sequence $(S_m)$ of nonempty closed subsets of $X$ with $$S_1 ⊇S_2 ⊇··· \mbox{and}\ \mbox{diam}(S_m)→0,$$ we have $\cap^∞S_i \neq∅$ (so that $|\cap^∞S_i|=1$). Lemma 1.6.15, Theorem 1.6.31: (Bolzano–Weierstrass Theorem in $\mathbb{R}$) Every bounded sequence in $\mathbb{R}$ has a convergent subsequence. Let $S$ be a bounded, infinite subset of $\mathbb{R}$. Then $S$ has an accumulation point in $\mathbb{R}$. Above two statements are equivalent, due to the definition of accumulation point. Note that only infinite sets have accumulation points. Finite sets can only consist of isolated points. Lemma 3.4.12, Theorem 3.4.14: (Bolzano–Weierstrass Theorem in $\mathbb{R}^n$) Every bounded sequence in $\mathbb{R}^n$ with the usual metric has a convergent subsequence. Let $S$ be a bounded, infinite subset of $\mathbb{R}^n$. Then $S$ has an accumulation point in $\mathbb{R}^n$. Above two statements are equivalent, due to the definition of accumulation point. Note that only infinite sets have accumulation points. Finite sets can only consist of isolated points. Theorem 1.6.24: (Cauchy Criterion in $\mathbb{R}$) A sequence in $\mathbb{R}$ is convergent iff it is Cauchy. Theorem 3: A metric space is compact iff, it is complete and totally bounded. A closed subset of a complete metric space is compact iff it is totally bounded. A subset $S$ of a metric space $X$ is totally bounded iff every sequence in $S$ has a Cauchy subsequence. Examples and ExercisesExample: $(0,1]$ is not complete as a metric subspace of $\mathbb{R} $, but would be complete with the discrete metric. $\mathbb{Q} $ is an incomplete metric space as a metric subspace of $\mathbb{R} $. $\mathbb{R} $ is complete but not compact. In fact, even a complete and bounded metric space need not be compact, the gap between completeness and compactness disappears if we strengthen the boundedness hypothesis here to total boundedness. $\mathbb{R}^{n,p},\ \ell^p$ is complete. $\mathbf{B}(T)$ is complete for any nonempty set $T$. $\mathbf{C}[0, 1]$ is a closed subset of $\mathbf{B}[0, 1]$, so it is complete. Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R}^n$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: The Completion of Metric Spaces
posts.text: Definitions $\tilde{X}$, Equivalence Class in $X’$: Let $X’$ be the set of all Cauchy sequences in $X$. We define an equivalence relation on $X’$ by saying that $(x_n)\sim(y_n)$ if $\lim_{n\to\infty} d(x_n,y_n)=0$ Let $\tilde{X}$ denote the set of equivalence classes of $X’$ The equivalent class of $(x_k)_{k∈\mathbb{N}}$ is denoted by $[x_k]$. $\tilde{d}$, Metric on $\tilde{X}$: Let $[x_n],[y_n]$ be in $\tilde{X}$. Note that $(d(x_n,y_n))_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ is a Cauchy sequence in $\mathbb{R}$. Indeed, let $\varepsilon>0$ be give, then there is $N\in\mathbb{N}$ such that , for all $m,n\geq N$, we have $d(x_n,x_m),d(y_n,y_m)<\frac{\varepsilon}{2}$. Then$$\begin{aligned}|d(x_n,y_n)-d(x_m,y_m)|&=|d(x_n,y_n)-d(x_n,y_m)|+|d(x_n,y_m)-d(x_m,y_m)|\&\leq d(y_n,y_m)+d(x_n,x_m)\&\leq \varepsilon\end{aligned}$$ Since $\mathbb{R}$ is complete, there is $d\geq0$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}d(x_n,y_n)=d$ We define $\tilde{d}([x_n],[y_n])=d$ as a metric on $\tilde{X}$ The Completion of $X$: We call $\tilde{X}$ the completion of $X$. Propositions and TheoremsTheorem 3.9.1: Let $(X,d)$ be a metric space. Then there exists a complete metric space $(X,d)$, and an injection $φ : X → \tilde{X}$, such that $φ:X→φ(X)$ is an isometry, and $φ(X)$ is dense in $\tilde{X}$. Define $φ:X→\tilde{X}$ by $φ(x)=[x_n]$ where $x_n=x$ for all $n\in\mathbb{N}$ Reference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R}^n$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: The Contraction Mapping Theorem
posts.text: DefinitionsContraction: Let $X$ be any metric space. A self-map $Φ$ on $X$ is said to be a contraction if there exists a real number $0 < K < 1$ such that $$d(Φ(x), Φ(y)) ≤ Kd(x, y)\ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ \ \ x, y ∈ X.$$ The infimum of the set of all such $K$ is called the contraction coefficient of $Φ$. In general, it may be quite difficult to check whether or not a given self-map is contractive. In most applications, however, one works with self-maps that are defined on relatively well-behaved metric spaces. $m$th Iteration: Let $X$ be a nonempty set, and $Φ$ a self-map on $X$. Let $Φ^1 := Φ$, and define $Φ^{m+1} :=Φ◦Φ^m$ for any $m=1,2,…. $ The self-map $Φ^m$ is called the $m$th iteration of $Φ$. Propositions and TheoremsLemma 3: (Blackwell’s Contraction Lemma) Let $T$ be a nonempty set, and $X $ a nonempty subset of $\mathbf{B}(T )$ which is closed under addition by positive constant functions. Assume that $Φ$ is an increasing self-map on $X$. If there exists a $0<\delta<1$ such that $$Φ(f + α) ≤ Φ(f) + δα\ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ \ \ (f, α) ∈ X × \mathbb{R}_+,$$ then $Φ$ is a contraction. Theorem 3.7.7: (The Contraction Mapping Theorem / The Banach Fixed Point Theorem) Let $X$ be a complete metric space. If $Φ ∈ X^X$ is a contraction, then there exists a unique $x^∗ ∈ X$ such that $Φ(x^∗) = x^∗$. Corollary 2: Let $X$ be a complete metric space. For any self-map $Φ$ on $X$ such that $Φ^m$ is a contraction for some $m ∈ \mathbb{N} $, there exists a unique $x^∗ ∈ X$ such that $Φ(x^∗) = x^∗$. The Generalized Banach Fixed Point Theorem 1. (Merryfield-Stein Jr.) Let $X$ be a complete metric space, and $Φ$ a self-map on $X$. If there exist a $(K,M) ∈ (0, 1) × \mathbb{N} $ such that $$\min{d(Φ^m(x),Φ^m(y)) : m = 1,…,M} ≤ Kd(x,y)\ \ \mbox{for all}\ \ x,y ∈ X,$$ then there exists an $x ∈X$ such that $Φ(x)=x$. The Generalized Banach Fixed Point Theorem 2: (Matkowski) Let $X$ be a complete metric space, and $f : \mathbb{R}_+ → \mathbb{R}_+$ an increasing function with $\lim f^m(t) = 0$ for all $t≥0$. If $Φ∈X^X$ satisfies $$d(Φ(x), Φ(y)) ≤ f (d(x, y))\ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ \ \ x, y ∈ X,$$ then there exists a unique $x ∈X$ such that $Φ(x)=x$. The Banach Fixed Point Property: Every contraction $Φ ∈ S^S$, where $S$ is a nonempty closed subset of $X$, has a fixed point. A metric space is complete iff it has the Banach Fixed Point Property. Examples and ExercisesPicard’s Existence Theorem: (The Local Version) Let $−∞ < a < b < ∞$, and $(x_0,y_0) ∈ (a,b)^2$ . If $H : [a,b]^2→ \mathbb{R} $ is continuous, and $$|H(x,y)−H(x,z)|≤α|y−z|,\ \ \ \ a≤x,y,z≤b,$$ for some $α > 0$, then there is a $δ > 0$ such that there exists a unique differentiable real function $f$ on $[x_0 − δ, x_0 + δ]$ with $y_0 = f(x_0)$ and $$f’(x)=H(x,f(x)),\ \ \ x_0−δ≤x≤x_0+δ.$$ Picard’s Existence Theorem: (The Global Version) Let $−∞ < a < b < ∞$, and $(x_0,y_0)∈[a,b]×\mathbb{R} $. If $H:[a,b]×\mathbb{R} →\mathbb{R} $ is continuous,and $$|H(x,y)−H(x,z)|≤α|y−z|,\ \ \ \ \ \ \ a≤x≤b,\ \ \ \ \ −∞<y,z<∞,$$ for some $α > 0$, then there exists a unique differentiable real function $f$ on $[a, b]$ with $y_0 = f(x_0)$ and$$f’(x)=H(x,f(x)),\ \ \ a≤x≤b.$$ Reference Efe A. posts.title: Continuity and Compactness
posts.text: Propositions and TheoremsProposition 3: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two metric spaces, and $f ∈ Y^X$ a continuous function. If $S$ is a compact subset of $X$, then $f(S)$ is a compact subset of $Y $. Proposition 3 is a very important observation and has many implications. First of all, it gives us a useful sufficient condition for the inverse of an invertible continuous function to be continuous. The Homeomorphism Theorem: If $X$ is a compact metric space and $f ∈ Y^X$ is a continuous bijection, then $f$ is a homeomorphism. Corollary 2: Any continuous real function $φ$ defined on a compact metric space $X$ is bounded. Local-to-global Method: For any given metric space $X$, suppose $Λ$ is a property (that may or may not be satisfied by the open subsets of $X$) such that $(\vartriangle)$ Λ is satisfied by an open neighborhood of every point in $X$; and $(\blacktriangledown) $If Λ is satisfied by the open subsets $O$ and $U$ of $X$, then it is also satisfied by $O ∪ U$. Then, if $X$ is compact, it must possess the property $Λ$. By compactness, we can deduce that $Λ$ is satisfied globally from the knowledge that it is satisfied locally. Weierstrass’ Theorem: If $X$ is a compact metric space and $φ ∈ \mathbb{R}^X$ is a continuous function, then there exist $x, y ∈ X$ with $φ(x) = \sup φ(X)$ and $φ(y) = \inf φ(X)$. Examples and ExercisesReference Efe A. Ok, 2005, “Real Analysis with Economic Applications”; John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Lecture notes and discussions at Piazza, Math 20300 51, Autumn 2020, Analysis in $\mathbb{R}^n$ 1; Terence Tao, 2006, “Analysis”; 周民强，2008，“实变函数论”； 周民强，2007，“实变函数解题指南”； 周民强，2010，“数学分析习题演练”； 夏道行，吴卓人，严绍宗，舒五昌，2010，“实变函数论与泛函分析“； 张筑生，1990，”数学分析新讲“；

posts.title: Continuity and Connectedness
posts.text: Propositions and TheoremsTheorem 3.6.36, Proposition 2: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two metric spaces, and $f ∈ Y^X$ a continuous function. If $X$ is connected, then $f(X)$ is a connected subset of $Y$. Corollary 3.6.37: (The Intermediate Value Theorem) Let $X$ be a connected metric space and $φ ∈ R^X$ a continuous function. If $φ(x) ≤ α ≤ φ(y)$ for some $x, y ∈ X$, then there exists a $z ∈ X$ such that $φ(z) = α$. Corollary 1: Given any $−∞ < a ≤ b < ∞$, any continuous self-map $f$ on $[a, b]$ has a fixed point. Examples and ExercisesExample: Proposition 2 and/or the Intermediate Value Theorem can sometimes be used to prove that a function is not continuous. For instance, Proposition 2 yields readily that there does not exist a continuous function that maps $[0, 1]$ onto $[0, 1]\setminus{ \frac{1}{2} }$. Reference Efe A.
