posts.text: DefinitionsFinitely Additive, $\sigma$-additive: Let $X$ be a nonempty set and $\mathcal{A}$ a collection of subsets of $X$ which constains $\empty$. A map $\mathbf{p}:\mathcal{A}\mapsto [0,+\infty]$ is said to be finitely additive (**$\sigma$-additive**, responsive.) if $\mathbf{p}(\empty)=0$ and $$\mathbf{p}(\bigsqcup\mathcal{S})=\sum_{S\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{p}(S)$$ for any nonempty finite (countable, resp.) set $\mathcal{S}$ of pariwise disjoint elements of $\mathcal{A}$ such that $\bigsqcup \mathcal{S}\in \mathcal{A}$. $\sigma$-additivity implies the likelihood of the union of countably many pairwise disjoint events is simply the sum of the individual probabilities of each of these events. The additivity property is the heart of the measure theory, entails several other useful properties for measures. Measure, Measure Space: Let $(X,\Sigma)$ be a measurable space. Any $\sigma$-additive function $\mu: \Sigma\mapsto[0,\infty]$ is called a measure on $\Sigma$, and in that case the ordered triplet $(X,\Sigma , \mu)$ is said to be a measure space. If $\mu(X) <\infty $; then $\mu$ is called a finite measure, and $(X,\Sigma ,\mu )$ is referred to as a finite measure space. If there is a countable subset $\mathcal{T}$ of $\Sigma$ such that $X =\bigsqcup \mathcal{T}$ and $\mu(T) < \infty$ for each $T\in \mathcal{T }$, we say that $\mu$ is a **$\sigma$-finite measure**, and refer to $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ as a **$\sigma$-finite measure space**. A useful interpretation is to think of a measure on $\Sigma$ as a function that tells us the “size” of each set in $\Sigma$ in some geometric sense. Depending on the context, for instance, this may correspond to, say, area or volume or mass, etc., of the members of $\Sigma$. Probability Measure, Probability Space: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ be a measure space. If $\mu(X) = 1$, then $\mu$ is said to be a probability measure, and in this case, $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ is called a probability space. Roughly speaking, a probability measure tells us the likelihood of observing any conceivable event in an experiment the outcome of which is uncertain. Borel Measure, Borel Space, Borel Probability Space: Given a metric space $X$, any measure $\mathbf{p}$ on $\mathcal{B}(X)$ is called a Borel measure on $X$, and in this case $(X,\mathcal{B}(X),\mathbf{p})$ is referred to as a Borel space. If, in addition, $\mathbf{p}$ is a probability measure, then $(X,\mathcal{B}(X),\mathbf{p})$ is called a Borel probability space. We denote the set of all Borel probability measures on a metric space $X$ by $\Delta(X)$. Regular: Let $X$ be a metric space and $\mathbf{p}\in\Delta(X)$. Let $\mathcal{O}_X$ and $\mathcal{C}_X$ denote the class of all open and closed subsets of $X$, respectively. A Borel measure $\mathbf{p}$ on a metric space $X$ is said to be regular if$$\inf{\mathbf{p}(O): S\subseteq O\in \mathcal{O}_X}=\mathbf{p}(S) = \sup \mathbf{p}(C) : {S\supseteq C\in \mathcal{C}_X}$$ holds for any $S\in \mathcal{B}(X)$. Much of the diffculty with working with probability measures stems from the fact that the contents of the $\sigma$-algebra of a probability space are often obscure. The situation reads markedly better in the case of Borel probability spaces, for the $\sigma$-algebra of such a space is generated by sets that are somewhat concrete (such as open (or closed) subsets of the sample space). Moreover, in the context of any Borel probability space, it is possible to approximate the probability of any event by using only the open and closed sets. Put more formally, if $X$ is a metric space and $\mathbf{p}\in\Delta(X)$, then, for any Borel subset $S$ of $X$ and $\varepsilon> 0$, we can find an open subset $O$ and a closed subset $C$ of $X$ such that $C\subseteq S\subseteq O$ and $\mathbf{p}(O\setminus C) <\varepsilon$. Every Borel probability measure is regular. Every finite Borel measure on a metric space is regular. Tight: A finite Borel measure $\mathbf{p}$ on a metric space $X$ is said to be tight if for each $\varepsilon > 0$, there is a compact subset $K$ of $X$ such that $p(X\backslash K) <\varepsilon$. Every Borel probability measure on a complete and separable metric space is tight. Propositions and TheoremsLemma 2.1: Let $\mathcal{S}$ be a semialgebra on a nonempty set $X$, and $\mathbf{q} : \mathcal{S}\mapsto [0,+\infty]$ a finitely additive map. Then, there is a unique finitely additive map $\mathbf{p} : \alpha(\mathcal{S})\mapsto[0,+\infty]$ such that $\mathbf{p}(S) = \mathbf{q}(S)$ for each $S \in \mathcal{S}$. Lemma 2.2: Let $\mathcal{S}$ be a semialgebra on a nonempty set $X$, and $\mathbf{q}: \mathcal{S} \mapsto [0,+\infty]$ a $\sigma$-additive map. Then, there is a unique $\sigma$-additive map $\mathcal{p}:\sigma(\mathcal{S})\mapsto [0,+\infty]$ such that $\mathbf{p}(S) = \mathbf{q}(S)$ for each $S\in \mathcal{S}$. Every finitely additive (finitely additive and $\sigma$-subadditive) $[0,\infty]$-valued map on a semialgebra $\mathcal{S}$ can be extended, uniquely, to a finitely additive ($\sigma$-additive) $[0,\infty]$-valued map on the algebra generated by $\mathcal{S}$. Lemma 2.3: Let $X$ be a nonempty set, $\mathcal{A}$ an algebra on $X$, and $\mu:\mathcal{A}\mapsto[0,\infty]$ a $\sigma$-additive map on $\mathcal{A}$. Then, $\mu$ is finitely additive. Consequently, $$\mu(B\backslash A)=\mu(B)-\mu(A)\mbox{ for any} A,B\in \mathcal{A}\ \mbox{with}\ A\subseteq B,$$ which shows that $\mu$ is $\supseteq$-increasing (that is, $\mu(A)\leq\mu(B)$ for any $A,B\in \mathcal{A}$ with $A\subseteq B$). Moreover,$$\mu(\bigcup\mathcal{S})\leq\sum_{S\in\mathcal{S}}\mu(S)$$ for any countable $\mathcal{S}\subseteq \mathcal{A}$ with $\bigcup\mathcal{S}\in\mathcal{A}$. Boole’s Inequality: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probability space. Then, $$\mathbf{p}(\bigcup\mathcal{S})\leq\sum_{S\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{p}(S)\ \mbox{for any nonempty countable}\ \mathcal{S}\subseteq\Sigma$$ Proposition 2.4: Let $(X,\Sigma, \mu)$ be a finite measure space, and let $(A_m)\in\Sigma^\infty$. If $A_1\subseteq A_2\subseteq\cdots$  (in which case we say that $(A_m)$ is an increasing sequence), then $$\lim\mu(A_m)=\mu\left(\bigcup^\infty_{i=1}A_i\right).$$ On the other hand, if $A_1\supseteq A_2\supseteq \cdots$  (in which case we say that $(A_m)$ is a decreasing sequence), then$$\lim\mu(A_m)=\mu \left(\bigcap^\infty_{i=1}A_i\right) .$$ These two properties of a finite measure measure are often referred to as the properties of continuity (from below and above, resp.) of a finite measure. Proposition 2.5: Let $X$ be a nonempty set, $\mathcal{A}$ be an algebra on $X$, and  $\mu:A\rightarrow [0,\infty]$ a finitely additive function such that $\mu(C_m)\downarrow 0$ for any $(C_m)\in A^\infty$ with $C_m\downarrow\empty$. Then, $\mu$ is $\sigma$-additive. Finite additivity and continuity of a set function jointly imply its $\sigma$-additivity. A finitely additive $[0,\infty]$-valued function on an algebra that is continuous from above at $\emptyset$ is $\sigma$-additive. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Constructing Probability Spaces
posts.text: DefinitionsDistribution Function: A map $F\in \mathbb{R} \rightarrow [0, 1]$ is said to be a distribution function if it is increasing, right-continuous, and $F(-\infty) = 0 = 1-F(\infty)$. Every Borel probability measure on $\mathbb{R}$ induces a distribution function in a natural manner. Indeed, it is easy to see that the map $t \mapsto\mathbf{p}(-\infty, t]$ on $\mathbb{R}$ is a distribution function for any $\mathbf{p}\in \Delta(\mathbb{R})$ Distribution function induced by $\mathbf{p}$: For any $\mathbf{p}\in \Delta(\mathbb{R})$, the map $F_\mathbf{p} :\mathbb{R}\to [0, 1]$ defined by $F (t) := \mathbf{p}(-\infty, t]$, is a distribution function. We refer to $F_\mathbf{p}$ the distribution function induced by $\mathbf{p}$. Lebesgue-Stieltjes Probability Measure induced by $F$ on $\mathbb{R} $: Let $\mathcal{S}$ be the semialgebra of all right-semiclosed intervals. Taking any distribution function $F$, define the map $\mathbf{q}\in[0, 1]^{\mathcal {S}}$ as $$\mathbf{q}(a,b]:=F(b)-F(a).\ \ \ -\infty\leq a\leq b<\infty$$ and$$\mathbf{q}(a,\infty):=1-F(a),\ \ \ \ -\infty\leq a.$$ The probability measure on $\sigma(\mathcal{S})=\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R} )$ which accords with $\mathbf{q}$, and denoted by $\mathbf{p}_F$ is called the Lebesgue-Stieltjes probability measure induced by $F$ on $\mathbb{R} $. Carathéodory’s Extension Theorem would then say that there is a unique extension of $\mathbf{q}$ to a probability measure on $\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R} )$. To prove $\mathbf{q}$ is $\sigma$-additive on $\mathcal{S}$, let us take any countably infinite set $\mathcal{T}$ of pairwise disjoint right-semiclosed intervals, and assume that $\bigsqcup{T}$ is itself a right-semiclosed interval, say, $(a,b]$. As things are trivial when $a = b$, we assume in what follows that $a < b$ We will assume here that $\bigsqcup \mathcal{T}$ is bounded from above, that is, it is an interval of the form $(a,b]$, where $-\infty\leq a < b <\infty$ Let us then enumerate $T$ as ${f(a_1, b_1], (a_2, b_2],\cdots}$. Then we can show that$$\mathbf{q}(a,b]=\sum^\infty_{i=1}\mathbf{q}(a_i,b_i].$$ A Borel probability measure on $\mathbb{R} $ can actually be identified with a distribution function. Lebesgue-Stieltjes probability measure induced by $F$ on $(a, b]$ / Lebesgue-Stieltjes measure induced by $F$ on $(a, b]$: If $X := (a, b]$ with $-\infty< a < b < \infty$, and $F \in [0,1]^X$ is an increasing and right-continuous function with $F(a+) = 0$ and $F(b) = 1$, then we can define the Lebesgue-Stieltjes probability measure induced by $F$ on $(a, b] $, analogously. Drop the conditions $F(a+) = 0$ and $F(b) = 1$, and allow $F \in \mathbb{R}^X$ then we can define the Lebesgue-Stieltjes measure induced by $F$ on $(a, b] $, analogously. Lebesque Measure on $\mathbb{R} $: Take any integer $i$, let $X_i := (i,i+1]$, and define $F_i : X_i \rightarrow [0,1]$ by $F_i(t) := t-i$. Let $\ell_i$ denote the Lebesgue-Stieltjes measure induced by $F_i$ on $X_i$ for each $i$ We define the Lebesgue measure on $\mathbb{R} $ as the $[0,\infty]$-valued map $\ell$ on $\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R} )$ with$$\ell(S):=\sum_{i\in\mathbb{Z}}\ell_i(S\cap X_i)$$ As such, $\ell$ is both regular and tight. Furthermore, it assigns to any interval its length as its measure. In particular, it is readily verified that $\ell(a, b] = b$ a for any real numbers $a$ and $b$ with $a < b$, while $\ell(I) = \infty$ for any unbounded interval $I$ Lebesque Measure on $\mathbb{R} $ is, geometrically speaking, the natural measure on the real line. This is indeed a $\sigma$-finite measure on $\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R} )$. The restriction of $\ell$ to any Borel subset $X$ of $\mathbb{R}$ is a Borel measure on $X$; that is, $(X,\mathcal{B}(X),\ell|_{\mathcal{B}(X)})$ is a Borel measure space for any $X\in\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R} )$. For brevity, we denote this measure space simply as $(X,\mathcal{B}(X),\ell)$ in what follows. For instance, $([0,1],\mathcal{B}([0,1]),\ell)$ is a Borel probability space. Propositions and TheoremsCarathéodory’s Extension Theorem: Let $\mathcal{S}$ be a semialgebra on a nonempty set $X$ and take any $\mathbf{q}: \mathcal{S}\rightarrow [0,\infty]$. If $\mathbf{q}$ is $\sigma$-additive, then there exists a measure $\mathbf{p}$ on $\sigma(\mathcal{S})$ such that $\mathbf{p}(S) = \mathbf{q}(S)$ for each $S \in \mathcal{S}$. Moreover, if $\mathbf{q}(X) < \infty$, then $\mathbf{p}$ is unique. We can always extend a $\sigma$-additive $[0,\infty]$-valued map on an algebra $\mathcal{A}$ to a $\sigma$-additive $[0,\infty]$-valued map on $\sigma(\mathcal{A})$ Moreover, this extension is unique, provided that our map is real-valued. We can always obtain a probability measure, uniquely, on a $\sigma$-algebra by specifying the behavior of the measure only on a semialgebra that generates this $\sigma$-algebra. Since semialgebras and algebras are often easier than $\sigma$-algebras to work with, this fact is quite useful in constructing probability measures. Proposition 3.1: For any real number a and Borel subset $S$ of $\mathbb{R} $, the set $S + a$ is Borel, and $\ell (S + a) =\ell (S)$. Proposition 3.4: Let $f$ be an additive self-map on $\mathbb{R} $. If $f$ is bounded on some Borel subset $S$ of $\mathbb{R} $ with $\ell(S) > 0$, then it is linear. Examples and ExercisesExample: Any singleton set in $\mathbb{R}$ has Lebesgue measure zero. Since the Lebesgue measure of any singleton is zero, so must be the Lebesgue measure of any countable subset of $\mathbb{R}$, because the $\sigma$-additivity of $\ell$ implies that $\ell{a_1, a_2\dots, } = \sum^\infty \ell{a_i}=0$ for any real sequence $(a_m)$. For instance: $\ell(\mathbb{Q}) = 0$ Example 3.5: There are in fact uncountable sets in $\mathbb{R}$ which have Lebesgue measure zero. For example, the Contor Set. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Spaces of Integrable Random Variables
posts.text: Definitions$p$-Integrable Let $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ be a measure space. For any real number $p\geq 1$, we define $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ as the set of all random variables $f$ on $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ such that $|f|^p$ is integrable. In other words,$$\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu):=\left{f\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma):\int_X|f|^pd\mu<\infty\right}$$ Any one member of $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ is said to be $p$-integrable. There is a natural way of making $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ a seminormed linear space. We define the real map $|\cdot|_p$ on $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ by$$|f|_p:=\left(\int_X|f|^pd\mu\right)^\frac{1}{p}$$It is not a normed linear space proper, because $|\cdot|_p$ identifies any two random variables that are distinct from each other only on a negligible set with respect to $\mu$. In other words, the map $(f, g) \mapsto |f- g|_p$ is a semimetric, but it is not a metric, for it fails to separate points in $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu)$. The problem is that $|f|p =0$ does not yield $f =\mathbf{0}$, it implies only that $f ={a.s.} \mathbf{0}$. $\mathcal{L}^p$-bounded: For any given real number $p\geq1$, we say that a set $\mathcal{X}$ of random variables on a given probability space is $\mathcal{L}^p$-bounded if either it is empty or$$\sup{\mathbb{E}(|x|^p):x\in\mathcal{X}}<\infty$$ $\mathcal{L}^p$-convergence: For any given real number $p\geq1$, let $x, x_1,x_2,\dots$ be random variables on $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ We say that $x_m$ is $\mathcal{L}^p$-convergent if$$\lim_{m\to\infty}|x_m-x|p=\lim{m\to\infty}\left(\int_X|x_m-x|^pd\mu\right)^\frac{1}{p}=\lim_{m\to\infty}\mathbb{E}(|x_m-x|^p)=0$$ $\mathcal{L}^1$-convergence is called convergence in the mean. $\mathcal{L}^p$-convergence is a natural notion of convergence for sequences in this semimetric space. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 5.4: Let $X$ be a nonempty set of random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. If $X$ is uniformly integrable, then it is $\mathcal{L}^1$-bounded. Proposition 5.5: Let $X$ be a set of random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. If $X$ is $\mathcal{L}^p$-bounded for some $p > 1$, then it is uniformly integrable. $$\mathcal{L}^p\mbox{-boundeness}\ \ (p>1)\Longrightarrow\mbox{uniform integrability}\Longrightarrow\mathcal{L}^1\mbox{-boundeness}$$ Proposition 5.6: Let $x, x_1,x_2,\dots$ be integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $\mathbb{E}(|x_m -x|) \to 0$. Then, $(x_m)$ is uniformly integrable. $$\mathcal{L}^1\mbox{-convergence}\Longrightarrow\mbox{uniform integrability}\Longrightarrow\mathcal{L}^1\mbox{-boundeness}$$ Proposition 5.7: Let $(x_m)$ be a uniformly integrable sequence of random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ such that $x_m\to_{a.s.} x$ for some $x \in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$ Then, $x$ is integrable and $\mathbb{E}(|x_m-x |) \to 0$. Almost sure convergence does imply $\mathcal{L}^1$-convergence for uniformly integrable sequences. Corollary 5.8: Let $x, x_1, x_2,\dots$ be integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $x_m\to_{a.s.} x$. Then, $\mathbb{E}(|x_m-x|) \to 0$ iff, $(x_m)$ is uniformly integrable. Examples and ExercisesExample 5.1: Almost sure convergence does not imply $\mathcal{L}^1$-convergence. Consider the sequence $(x_m)$ of random variables on the probability space $([0,1],\mathcal{B}[0,1],\ell)$ where $x_m$ equals $m$ on $[0,\frac{1}{m}]$ and $0$ elsewhere on $[0,1]$. Then, $x_m(\omega) \to0$ for each $\omega\in (0,1]$, and hence, $x_m \to_{a.s.} 0$. But $|x_m|_1 = 1$ for each $m$. Example 5.2: $\mathcal{L}^1$-convergence does not imply almost sure convergence. Consider $(x_m) := (\mathbf{1}{[0,1)},\mathbf{1}{[0,\frac{1}{2})}, \mathbf{1}{[\frac{1}{2},1)},\mathbf{1}{[0,\frac{1}{3})}, \mathbf{1}{[\frac{1}{3},\frac{2}{3})},\mathbf{1}{[\frac{2}{3},1)},\dots),$ which is a sequence in $\mathcal{L}^1([0,1),\mathcal{B}[0,1),\ell)$. Clearly, we have $\mathbb{E}(x_m)\to 0$, that is, $|x_m|_1\to 0$. But $ (x_m(\omega))$ does not converge to a real number for any $\omega$ in $[0, 1)$. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Elementary Probability Inequalities
posts.text: Propositions and TheoremsJensen’s Inequality: Let $x$ be an integrable random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$, $I$ an open interval that contains $x(X)$, and $\varphi : I \to \mathbb{R}$ a concave function. Then, $\varphi \circ x \in \mathcal{L}^0(X ,\Sigma)$ and$$\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x) \leq \varphi(\mathbb{E}(x))$$ If $\varphi$ is convex, then the inequality goes the other direction. Under fairly general conditions, the expectation of a concave transformation of a random variable $x$ is always less than the same transformation of the expectation of $x$ Lemma 4.1: Let $Y$ be a metric space, and $x$ a $Y$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Then, for any continuous $\varphi: Y \to \mathbb{R}_+$ and real number $\lambda > 0$, we have$$\mathbf{p}{\varphi\circ x\geq \lambda}\leq\frac{1}{\lambda}\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x).$$ Markov’s Inequality: Let $Y$ be a normed metric space, and $x$ a $Y$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Then, for any real number $\lambda > 0$, we have$$\mathbf{p}{| x|_Y\geq \lambda}\leq\frac{1}{\lambda}\mathbb{E}(| x|_Y).$$ In particular, for any random variable $x$ on $(x,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$$$\mathbf{p}{| x|\geq \lambda}\leq\frac{1}{\lambda}\mathbb{E}(| x|).$$ The Chebyshev-Bienaymé Inequality: For any random variable $x$ defined on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, and any real number $\lambda> 0$, we have$$\mathbf{p}{| x|\geq \lambda}\leq\frac{1}{\lambda^2}\mathbb{E}(x^2).$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: The Expectation Functional of Arbitrary Random Variables
posts.text: DefinitionsExpectation of Arbitrary Random Variables: Let $x$ be an $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Note that $x^+ := \max{x, 0}$ and $x^- := \max{-x,0}$ are $[0, \infty]$-valued random variables on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ with $x = x^++ x^-$ Define the expectation of $x$ as the (extended real) number $\mathbb{E}(x) := \mathbb{E}(x^+) -\mathbb{E}(x^-)$, provided that $\mathbb{E}(x^+)$ and $\mathbb{E}(x^-)$ are not both infinite. If $\mathbb{E} (x^+) = \infty = \mathbb{E}(x^-)$, we say that the expectation of $x$ does not exist. This definition generalizes the one we gave for the expectation of $[0,\infty]$-valued random variables. In real analysis, $\mathbb{E}(x)$ is called the Lebesgue integral of $x$ (with respect to $\mathbf{p}$), and is denoted by $\int_Xxd\mathbf{p}$. Variance of Arbitrary Random Variables: In turn, the variance of an arbitrary random variable $x$ on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ is the number$$\mathbb{V}(x) := \mathbb{E}((x - \mathbb{E}(x))^2)$$ where $(x-\mathbb{E}(x))^2$ is the arbitrary random variable $\omega\mapsto (x(\omega) -\mathbb{E}(x))^2$ on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. However, it is often more convenient to use the alternate formula$$\mathbb{V}(x) := \mathbb{E}(x^2) - \mathbb{E}(x)^2$$ Integrable: $x$ is integrable (with respect to $\mathbf{p}$) if $\mathbb{E}(|x|)=\mathbb{E}(x^+)+\mathbb{E}(x^-)<\infty$ . $\mathbb{E}(x)$ exists iff $\min{\mathbb{E}(x^+), \mathbb{E}(x^-)} < \infty$, iff either $\mathbb{E}(x^+)$ or $\mathbb{E}(x^-)$ is finite $x$ is integrable iff $\max{\mathbb{E}(x^+), \mathbb{E}(x^-)} < \infty$, iff both $\mathbb{E}(x^+)$ and $\mathbb{E}(x^-)$ is finite $x$ is integrable iff $\mathbb{E}(x)$ exists and it is finite. Integrability of a random variable means simply that the expectation of this random variable is a real number. Lebesgue Integration of Aribitrary Maps: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ be a measure space. $f : X\to \overline{\mathbb{R}}$ a -measurable map. The Lebesgue integral of $f$ (with respect to $\mu$) is defined as the (extended real) number$$\int_Xfdu:=\int_Xf^+d\mu-\int_Xf^-d\mu$$ provided that the right-hand side of this expression is not of the $\infty-\infty$ form. If the latter condition is not met, we say that the Lebesgue integral of $f$ (with respect to $\mu$) does not exist. For any $S\in\Sigma$, we also define$$\int_Sfd\mu:=\int_X\mathbf{1}_Sd\mu,$$ provided that the right-hand side of this expression exists. Integrable: $f$ is integrable (with respect to $\mu$) if $\int_X |f|d\mu < \infty$. Uniform Integrable: A collection $\mathcal{X}$ of random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ is said to be uniformly integrable (with respect to $\mathbf{p}$) if$$\lim_{ a\to\infty}\sup\left{ \int_{ { \vert x\vert>a} }\vert x\vert d\mathbf{p}:x\in\mathcal{X} \right }=0$$ that is, for every $\varepsilon > 0$, there is a real number $a > 0$ such that$$\int_{ {|x|>a } }|x|d\mathbf{p}<\varepsilon \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ for each }x\in\mathcal{X}$$ In turn, a sequence $(x_m)$ of random variables on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ is called uniformly integrable if ${x_1, x_2,\dots}$ is uniformly integrable Propositions and TheoremsProposition 2.1: For any $\mathbb{R}$-valued random variable $x$ on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $\mathbb{E}(x)$ exists, we have $|\mathbb{E}(x)| \leq \mathbb{E}(|x|)$ Proposition 2.2: Let $x$ and $y$ be $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. For any real number $a$, we have $\mathbb{E}(ax) = a\mathbb{E}(x)$, provided that $\mathbb{E}(x)$ exists. Furthermore, $\mathbb{E}(x + y) = \mathbb{E}(x) + \mathbb{E}(y)$, provided that $x + y\in \overline{\mathbb{R}}^X$, $\mathbb{E}(x)$ exists, and $y$ is integrable. The set of all integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ is denoted by $\mathcal{L}^1(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, that is,$$\mathcal{L}^1(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p}):=\left{x\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p}):\int_X|x|d\mathbf{p}\right}$$$\mathcal{L}^1(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ is a linear subspace of $\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$. The map $\mathbb{E}$ acts as a linear functional on this linear space. Proposition 2.3: Let $x$ and $y$ be $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. If both $\mathbb{E}(x)$ and $\mathbb{E}(y)$ exist, then$$x\geq_{a.s.}y\ \ \ \ \mbox{ implies }\ \ \ \ \mathbb{E}(x) \geq \mathbb{E}(y)$$ Corollary 2.4: Let $x$ and $y$ be $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. If both $\mathbb{E}(x)$ and $\mathbb{E}(y)$ exist, then$$x=_{a.s.}y\ \ \ \ \mbox{ implies }\ \ \ \ \mathbb{E}(x) = \mathbb{E}(y)$$ The Monotone Convergence Theorem 2: Let $x, x_1,x_2,\dots$ be $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Then,$$\mathbb{E}(x_1)>-\infty,\ \ \ x_m \uparrow_{a.s.} x\ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ implies }\ \ \ \ \ \ \mathbb{E}(x_m)\uparrow \mathbb{E}(x)$$ The Change of Variables Formula: Let $Y$ be a metric space, $x$ a $Y$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, and $\varphi$ an $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variable on $(Y,\mathcal{B}(Y ),\mathbf{p}_x)$. If either $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{p}_x} (\varphi)$ or $\mathbb{E}_\mathbf{p}(\varphi\circ x)$ exists, then$$\int_Y\varphi d\mathbf{p}_x=\int_X(\varphi\circ x)d\mathbf{p}$$ The Change of Variables Formula remains valid in the context of any measure space. Note that when $Y = \mathbb{R} $, the distribution function induced by $\mathbf {p}_x $is the distribution function of $x$, and denoted by $F_x$. And the distribution induced by $F_x$ is the Lebesgue-Stieltjes probability measure actually, that is $\mathbf{p}_x=\ell_x$ Examples and ExercisesExample 2.5: Let $x$ be a nonnegative random variable on a probability space $\mathbb(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $x(X)$ is countable. The Change of Variables Formula says that the expectation of $x$ equals the Lebesgue integral of the identity function on $x(X)$ with respect to the probability measure $\mathbf{p}_x$. Therefore,$$\mathbb{E}(x)=\sum_{a\in x(X)}a\mathbf{p}{x=a}$$ Example 2.6, Geometric distribution: Take any $p\in (0,1)$ and let $x$ be an $\mathbb{N}$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ such that $\mathbf{p}{x = i} = p(1-p)^{i-1}$ for each $i\in\mathbb{N}$. Such a random variable is said to have a geometric distribution with parameter $p$.$$\mathbb{E}(x)=p+2p(1-p)+3p(1-p)^2 +\cdots=\frac{p}{1-p}\sum^\infty_{i=1}i(1-p)^i=\frac{p}{1-p}\frac{1-p}{1-(1-p)^2}=\frac{1}p$$ Example 2.7, Poisson distribution: Given a positive real number  $\lambda> 0$, a $\mathbb{Z}_+$-valued random variable $x$ on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ such that$$\mathbf{p}{x=i}=\frac{e^{-\lambda}\lambda^i}{i!},\ \ \ i=0,1,\dots$$ is said to have a Poisson distribution with parameter $\lambda$. Since $e^\lambda=1+\lambda+\frac{\lambda^2}{2}+\frac{\lambda^3}{3!}+\cdots$ We have $\mathbb{E}(x)=\lambda$, $\mathbb{E}(x^2)=\lambda+\lambda^2$ and $\mathbb{V}(x)=\lambda$. Example: Consider the experiment of throwing a single die, that is, the probability space $(X, 2^X,\mathbf{p})$ where $X := [6]$ and $\mathbf{p}(S) := \frac{|S|}{6} $ for all $S\in 2^X$. Consider the random variable $x\in[2]^X$ which is defined as$$x(\omega):=\left{\begin{matrix}1,&\mbox{ if }\omega\mbox{ is even}\2, &\mbox{ if }\omega\mbox{ is odd}\end{matrix}\right.$$ In addition, define $\varphi : [2] \to \mathbb{R}$ by $\varphi(t) := t^2$, and observe that $\varphi$ is a ${1,4}$-valued random variable on $([2], 2^{[2]},\mathbf{p}_x)$. Clearly, we have $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{p}_x} (\varphi) = (1) \frac{1}{2} + (4) \frac{1}{2} = \frac{5}{2}$. On the other hand, $\varphi\circ x$ is a ${1,4}$-valued random variable on $(X,2^X,\mathbf{p})$ that takes value $1$ if the outcome of the experiment is even and $4$ if the outcome is odd. Thus, we have $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{p}} (\varphi\circ x) = (1) \frac{1}{2} + (4) \frac{1}{2} = \frac{5}{2}$. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: The Expectation Functional of Simple Random Variables
posts.text:
DefinitionsExpectation of Simple Random Variables: Let $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ be a probability space. The set of all simple random variables on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ is a linear space relative to the pointwise defined addition and scalar multiplication operations. By definition, for any simple random variable $x$ on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$, we have $|x(X)| < \infty$ and$$x=\sum_{a\in x(X)}a\mathbf{1}_{x=a}$$ where $\mathbf{1}_{ {x=a} }$ stands for the indicator function of the event ${x = a}\in\Sigma$ on $X$. We define the expectation of any such $x$ as the real number$$\mathbb{E}(x):=\sum_{a\in x(X)}a\mathbf{p}{x=a}$$ Thus, the expected value of $x$ is the weighted average of its values, where the weight of $a$ is $\mathbf{p}x{a}$ for each $a\in x(X)$. That is, $\mathbf{E}(x) =\sum{a\in x(X)}\mathbf{p}_x{a}$. Linearity of $\mathbb{E}$:$$\mathbb{E}(x+y)=\mathbb{E}(x)+\mathbb{E}(y)$$Monotonicity of $\mathbb{E}$:$$\mathbb{E}(x) \geq \mathbb{E}(y)\mbox{ whenever }x\geq_{a.s.}y$$ $$\mathbb{E}(x)= \mathbb{E}(y)\mbox{ whenever }x=_{a.s.}y$$ Variance of Simple Random Variables: The variance of a simple random variable $x$ on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ is the number$$\mathbb{V}(x) := \mathbb{E}((x - \mathbb{E}(x))^2)$$ where $(x-\mathbb{E}(x))^2$ is the simple random variable $\omega\mapsto (x(\omega) -\mathbb{E}(x))^2$ on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. However, it is often more convenient to use the alternate formula$$\mathbb{V}(x) := \mathbb{E}(x^2) - \mathbb{E}(x)^2$$ Expectation of Nonnegative Random Variables Let $x$ be a $[0, \infty]$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. We define the expectation of $x$ as the (extended real) number$$\mathbb{E}(x) := \sup{\mathbb{E}(z) : z \in \mathfrak{L}(x)}$$ where $\mathfrak{L}(x)$ stands for the set of all simple random variables $z$ such that $z\leq x$. In turn, the variance of $x$ is defined as the (extended real) number$$\mathbb{V}(x) := \mathbb{E}((x - \mathbb{E}(x))^2),$$ provided that $\mathbb{E}(x) < \infty$. where $(x-\mathbb{E}(x))^2$ is the simple random variable $\omega\mapsto (x(\omega) -\mathbb{E}(x))^2$ on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. These definitions agree with those in the case of simple random variables on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Moreover, they extend those definitions to the case of $[0,\infty]$-valued simple random variables. In words, the (extended real) number $\mathbb{E}(x)$ is defined as the supremum of the weighted averages of all those simple random variables that are “smaller than” $x$ everywhere. So, in this sense, the idea behind the definition of $\mathbb{E}(x)$ is reminiscent of that of the computation of the area under a given curve in $\mathbb{R}	imes \mathbb{R}_+$ by approximating this area with the sum of the areas of the rectangles that lie under the curve and above the horizontal axis. Put this way, you should see that $\mathbb{E}(x)$ can be thought of as some sort of an integral of $x$ – it is called the Lebesgue integral of $x$ with respect to $\mathbf{p}$ –where the sets in the domain of $x$ (analogous to the bases of the rectangles under the curve) are “measured” according to the underlying probability measure. The commonly used notation for the Lebesgue integral of $x$ on $X$ with respect to $\mathbf{p}$ is $\int_Xxdp$, that is$$\int_X xd\mathbf{p}\ \mbox{ and }\ \mathbb{E}(x)$$denote the same (extended real) number. Adopting the widely used conventions of integration theory, we also set$$\int_Sxd\mathbf{p}:=\mathbb{E}(x\mathbf{1}_S)\mbox{ for any } S\in \Sigma,$$where $\mathbf{1}_S$ is the indicator function of $S$ on $X$. Therefore, recalling the definition of the expectation of a simple random variable, we see that $\int_S d\mathbf{p}$, that is, the Lebesgue integral of the constant function $1$ with respect to $\mathbf{p}$ on $S$, and $\mathbb{E}(\mathbf{1}_S )$ denote the same number, namely, $\mathbf{p}(S)$, for any $S\in\Sigma$. Many authors write$$\int_X x(\omega)\mathbf{p}(dw)$$instead of $\int_Xxd\mathbf{p}$. The Lebesgue integral of the map $\omega\mapsto\omega^2$ on the probability space $([0,1],\mathcal{B}[0,1],\ell)$ is, for instance, written as $\int_{[0,1]}\omega^2\ell(d\omega)$. Lebesgue Integration of Simple Maps: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mu )$ be a measure space. By a nonnegative simple $\Sigma$-measurable map on $X$, we mean a real function $f\in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$ such that $f\geq0$ and $f(X)$ is finite. The Lebesgue integral of any such map with respect to $\mu$ is defined as the number$$\int_Xfd\mu:=\sum_{a\in f(X)}a\mu{f=a},$$ where we adopt the convention that $0\cdot\infty$ equals $0$. Lebesgue Integration of Nonnegative Maps: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ be a measure space. The Lebesgue integral of any $\Sigma$-measurable $f : X 	o [0, \infty]$ with respect to $\mu$ is defined as the (extended) real number$$\int_X fd\mu:=\sup{\int_Xhd\mu:h\in\mathfrak{M}(f)}$$ where $\mathfrak{M}(f)$ stands for the set of all nonnegative simple $\Sigma$-measurable maps $h$ on $X$ with $h\leq f$. In turn, we define$$\int_S fd\mu:=\int_X f\mathbf{1}_S d\mu\ \ \ \ \mbox{ for any }S\in\Sigma$$ where $\mathbf{1}_S$ is the indicator function of $S$ on $X$. $\sigma$-finite Measure: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mu)$ be a measure space. We say that this space (or $\mu$ itself) is $\sigma$-finite if there is a countable partition $\mathcal{S}$ of $X$ such that $\mathcal{S}\subseteq \Sigma$ and $\mu(S) < \infty$ for each $S \in\mathcal{S}$ Absolutely Continuous, Density Function, Density: Let $F$ be a distribution function. We say that $F$ is absolutely continuous (with respect to the Lebesgue measure) if there is a Borel measurable map $f : \mathbb{R} 	o \mathbb{R}+$ such that$$F(t)=\int{(-\infty,t]}fd\ell$$ for every real number $t$. When this is the case, we say that $F$ is induced by the density function $f$, and refer to $f$ as a density for $F$. When $f$ is a density for $F$, $F(t)-F(s)=\int_{(s,t]}fd\ell$ for any real numbers $s$ and $t$ with $t > s$. Some distribution functions do not have closed form decriptions, but they are rather defined through integrating a density function. The most important example of such a function is the so-called normal distribution function (with parameters $\mu $ and $\sigma$). For any given real numbers $\mu$ and $\sigma>0$, this function $F$ is defined by$$f(t)= rac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{ rac{(t-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}$$for any real number $t$, it is thus trivially absolutely continuous. If  $\mu= 0$ and $\mu = 1$ here, this function is called the standard normal distribution function. Not all distribution function arises from a density funtion. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 1.1: For any $[0,\infty]$-valued random variables $x$ and $y$ (on a given probability space),$$x\geq_{a.s.}y\ \ \ \ \mbox{ implies }\ \ \ \ \mathbb{E}(x) \geq \mathbb{E}(y)$$ $$x=_{a.s.}y\ \ \ \ \mbox{ implies }\ \ \ \ \mathbb{E}(x) = \mathbb{E}(y)$$ The Monotone Convergence Theorem 1: Let $x, x_1,x_2,\dots$ be $[0,\infty]$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Then,$$x_m \uparrow_{a.s.} x\ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ implies }\ \ \ \ \ \ \mathbb{E}(x_m)\uparrow \mathbb{E}(x)$$ Proposition 1.2: Let $x$ and $y$ be two $[0,\infty]$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Then, for any $a\geq 0$,$$\mathbb{E}(ax+y)=a\mathbb{E}(x)+\mathbb{E}(y)$$ Proposition 1.3: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mu )$ be a finite measure space. Then, there is a real number  $\lambda\geq 0$ and a probability measure $\mathbf{p}$ on $\Sigma$ such that$$\int_Xfd\mu=\lambda\int_Xfd\mathbf{p}$$ for every $\Sigma$-measurable $f : X 	o [0,\infty]$. Proposition 1.5: Given any measure space $(X,\Sigma,\mu )$,$$\int_x(af+g)d\mu=a\int_Xfd\mu+\int_Xgd\mu$$ for every $a\geq0$ and $\Sigma$-measurable $f : X 	o [0,\infty]$. Proposition 1.6: Every absolutely continuous distribution function is uniformly continuous. If a distribution function is not continuous even at a single point, then it cannot possibly possess a density. The converse of Proposition 1.6 is false. Indeed, even a continuous distribution function need not possess a density. Proposition 1.7: Let $(X,\Sigma,

Then, $F$ is absolutely continuous iff, $\mathbf{p}_F$ is absolutely continuous with respect to $\ell$. Examples and ExercisesExample 1.1, Binomial Distribution: Let $n$ be a positive integer and $p$ a number in $[0, 1]$. A ${0,\dots, n}$-valued random variable $x$ on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that$$\mathbf{p}{x=i}=\left( egin{matrix}n\ i\end{matrix}ight)p^i(1-p)^{n-i},\ \ \ \ i=0,\dots,n$$ is said to have a binomial distribution with parameters $n$ and $p$ If $n = 1$ here, we say that $x$ has a Bernoulli distribution with parameter $p$ When $n = 1$, we have $\mathbb{E}(x) = p(1) + (1-p)(0) = p$, that is, the expected value of any random variable that has a Bernoulli distribution with parameter $p$ is $p$. In this case, we also find that $\mathbb{E}(x^2) = p$, so $\mathbb{V}(x) = p -p^2$ More generally, for any random variable that has a binomial distribution with parameters $n$ and $p$, we have$$\mathbb{E}(x)=\sum^n_{i=0}\left( egin{matrix}n\ i \end{matrix}ight)p^i(1-p)^{n-i}i=np\sum^{n-1}_{i=0}\left( egin{matrix}n-1\ i \end{matrix}ight)p^i(1-p)^{(n-1)-i}$$ so, by the Binomial Theorem, $\mathbb{E}(x) = np(p + (1 -p))^{n-1} = np$. By using a similar method, we can also show that $\mathbb{E}(x^2) = n^2 p^2 -np^2 + np$, so $\mathbb{V}(x) = np(1-p)$. Example 1.3: Let $(X,2^X,\mathbf{p})$ be a probability space with $X$ being a countable set. We wish to find an expression for the expectation of an arbitrary nonnegative random variable $x$ on $(X,2^X,\mathbf{p})$. Assume that $X$ is countably infinite, and enumerate it as $X := {\omega_1,\omega_2,\dots}$. For every positive integer $m$, let us define the simple random variable$$x_m(\omega)=\left{ egin{matrix}x(\omega),&\mbox{ if }\omega\in{\omega_1,\dots,\omega_m}\0,&\mbox{otherwise}\end{matrix}ight.$$ By definition of $\mathbb{E}$ for simple random variables, we have $\mathbb{E}(x_m) =\sum_{i\in[m]} x(\omega_i)\mathbf{p}{\omega_i}$ for each $m$. But, $x_m \uparrow x$, so we have $\mathbb{E}(x_m)\uparrow \mathbb{E}(x)$ by the Monotone Convergence Theorem 1. Consequently,$$\mathbb{E}(x)=\lim\mathbb{E}(x_m)=\lim\sum_{i\in[m]}x(\omega_i)\mathbf{p}{\omega_i}=\sum^\infty_{i=1}x(\omega_i)\mathbf{p}{\omega_i}=\sum_{x\in X}x(\omega)\mathbf{p}{\omega}$$ for any nonnegative random variable $x$ on $(X,2^X,\mathbf{p})$. Example 1.5: For any real numbers $a$ and $b$ with $a < b$, the uniform distribution $F$ on $[a,b]$ is absolutely continuous. The map $f:\mathbb{R}	o\mathbb{R}+$ where$$f(t)=\left{ egin{matrix} rac{1}{a-b},&0\leq t\leq b\0,&\mbox{otherwise}\end{matrix}ight.$$ is a density for that distribution function. Similarly, for any $\lambda > 0$, the exponential distribution with parameter $\lambda$ ,is absolutely continuous. The map $f:\mathbb{R}	o\mathbb{R}+$ where$$f(t)=\left{ egin{matrix}\lambda e^{-\lambda t},& t\geq 0\0,&\mbox{otherwise}\end{matrix}ight.$$ is a density for that distribution function. posts.title: Random Variables
posts.text: One is often interested in a particular characteristic of the (uncertain) outcomes of an experiment. To deal with such situations we may want to transform the given probability space (that models the underlying experiment) into another probability space the sample space of which contains the set of all values of the characteristic that we are interested in. This is achieved by means of a measurable function, which is more commonly referred to as a random variable in probability theory. In the most general sense of the term, such a function maps one measurable space into another. However, most measurable functions that are encountered in practice map a measurable space into a metric space, leading to the notion of Borel measurability. DefinitionsMeasurable: Let $(X_1,\Sigma_1)$ and $(X_2,\Sigma_2)$ be two measurable spaces. We say that a function $f : X_1\rightarrow X _2$ is **$\Sigma_1\backslash\Sigma_2$-measurable** if $f^{-1}(S) \in \Sigma_1$ for every $S \in \Sigma_2 $. Random Variable, $\Sigma$-Measurable Real Function, Borel Measurable: Let $(X,\Sigma)$ be a measurable space and $Y$ a metric space. A function $x : X\rightarrow Y$ is called a $Y$-valued random variable on $(X,\Sigma)$ if it is $\Sigma\backslash \mathcal{B}(Y)$-measurable, that is, if $x^{-1}(S)\in\Sigma$  for every $S\in \mathcal{B}(Y )$. An $\mathbb{R} $-valued random variable is simply called a random variable on $(X,\Sigma)$. The set of all random variables on a measurable space $(X,\Sigma )$ is denoted by $\mathcal {L}^0(X,\Sigma)$. Moreover, we define$$L^0_+(X,\Sigma) := {x \in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma) : x\geq 0}.$$ In real analysis what we call here a random variable on $(X,\Sigma )$ is called a $\Sigma$-measurable real function on $X$. Furthermore, a ($Y$-valued) random variable on a Borel probability space is said to be Borel measurable. Let $(X,\Sigma)$ be a measurable space and $Y$ a metric space. In principle, to verify that a map $x:X\to Y$ is a $Y$-valued random variable, we need to show that $x^{-1}(B)\in\Sigma$ for every Borel subset $B$ of $Y$ . Fortunately, there is a nice short-cut. If we can find a collection $\mathcal{A}$ of subsets of $Y$ that generates $\mathcal{B}(Y)$ and if we manage to verify that $x^{-1}(\mathcal{A})$  for every $A\in\mathcal{A}$ we may then conclude that $x$ is a $Y$-valued random variable. For instance, if$$x^{-1}(O)\in\Sigma\mbox{ for every open subset }O \mbox{ of }Y,$$or$$x^{-1}(C)\in\Sigma\mbox{ for every closed subset }C \mbox{ of }Y,$$then $x$ is sure to be a $Y$-valued random variable. The fact that the set of all intervals of the form $(-\infty,a]$, or of the form $(1,a)$, generates $\mathcal{B}(\mathbb{R})$ is used frequently, so it is probably a good idea to state it separately. Given any measurable space $(X,\Sigma)$ and a map $x : X \rightarrow \mathbb{R} $, we have$$x\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)\mbox{ iff }{\omega\in X:x(\omega)\leq a}\in\Sigma\ \mbox{ for every } a\in\mathbb{R}$$ and$$x\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)\mbox{ iff }{\omega\in X:x(\omega)< a}\in\Sigma\ \mbox{ for every } a\in\mathbb{R}$$ In measure theory and probability, we simply write ${x \leq a}$ for the set ${ \omega\in X : x(\omega) \leq a}$. While it may take a bit getting used to at first, this type of shorthand notation simplifies complex expressions considerably. For instance, with this notational convention, they we have$$x\in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)\mbox{ iff }{x\leq a}\in\Sigma\ \mbox{ for every } a\in\mathbb{R}$$In what follows, we will work with these sorts of expressions routinely. All you need to do is to remember that, given a probability (or measure) space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$, the set$${\mbox{a statement about random variables defined on this space}}$$equals, by convention,$${\omega\in X :\mbox{ this statement is true}}$$For any $x,y \in \mathcal{L}^0(X )$, the event that the absolute value of the difference between $x$ and $y$ is strictly larger than $3$ is written as ${|x-y|> 3} $ instead of the mouthful ${\omega\in X : |x(\omega) -y(\omega)| > 3}$. In turn, the probability of this event is written simply as $\mathbf{p}{|x- y| > 3}$: Random $n$-vector, Random Real Sequence, Random Bounded Map, Random Element: An $\mathbb{R}^n$-valued random variable as a random $n$-vector if $n \geq 2$. Analogously, an $\mathbb{R}^{\infty}$-valued random variable may be called a random real sequence A $\mathbf{B}[0,1]$-valued random variable is a random bounded map on $[0,1]$ and so on. More generally, a $Y$-valued random variable (for any metric space $Y$) is sometimes referred to as a random element of $Y$. Simple: Let $Y$ be a metric space. A $Y$-valued random variable $x$ is called simple if it takes finitely many values, that is, when the range of $x$ is a finite set. Postive Parts, Negative Parts: Let $X$ be a nonempty set and $x$ an $\overline{\mathbb{R} }$-valued function on $X$: We define the positive and negative parts of $x$ as $$x^+:= \max {x, 0}\mbox{ and }x^-:= \max {-x,0}$$ respectively. Clearly, both $x^+$ and $x^-$ are $[0, \infty]$-valued functions on $X$, and we have$$x=x^+ -x^-$$ The absolute value of $x$ is also decomposed into these two functions as follows:$$|x|=x^+ +x^-$$ It is plain that the positive and negative parts of an $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued function inherits the measurability of that function. In other words, if $x$ is an $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, then both $x^+$ and $x^-$ are $[0,\infty]$-valued random variables on $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Conversely, if $x^+$ and $x^-$ are $[0,\infty]$-valued random variables on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, then $x$ must itself be an $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variable on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 1.1: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two metric spaces, and $x: X \rightarrow Y$ a map that is continuous at all but countably many points. Then, $x$ is a $Y $-valued random variable on $(X,\mathcal{B}(X))$. Continuity at everywhere but countably many points is suffcient for Borel measurability. The converse is false. Even a map that is discontinuous everywhere may be Borel measurable. Proposition 1.2: Let $(X_i,\Sigma_ i)$ be a measurable space for each $i \in [3]$. If $f : X_1 \rightarrow X_2$ is a $\Sigma_1\backslash\Sigma_2$-measurable map and $g : X_2 \rightarrow X_3$ is a $\Sigma_2\backslash\Sigma_3$-measurable map, then $g \circ f$ is a $\Sigma_1\backslash\Sigma_3$-measurable map from $X_1$ into $X_3$. Proposition 1.5: Let $Y$ be a metric space and $(x_m)$ a sequence of $Y $-valued random variables on a measurable space $(X,\Sigma )$ such that $x_m\rightarrow x $ for some function $x: X \rightarrow Y$ . Then, $x$ is a $Y $-valued random variable on $(X,\Sigma )$. If $(x_m)$ is a sequence of metric space-valued random variables on some measurable space, $\lim x_m$ is well-defined as a random variable on that space This is unlike what is the case with continuous functions. Corollary 1.6: Let $(x_m)$ be an increasing sequence of $\overline{\mathbb{R} }$-valued random variables on a measurable space $(X,\Sigma )$. Then, $\lim x_m$ is an $\overline{\mathbb{R}}$-valued random variable on $(X,\Sigma )$. Theorem 1.7: Let $Y$ be a compact metric space and $x$ a $Y $-valued random variable on a measurable space $(X,\Sigma)$. Then, there is a sequence $(x_m)$ of simple $Y$-valued random variables on $(X,\Sigma )$ such that $x_m\rightarrow x$ uniformly. For a random variable with compact range, we can approximate a given random variable on a measurable space by means of simple random variables on that space. Examples and ExercisesExample 1.1: If $X$ is a nonempty set and $Y$ a metric space, then any map from $X$ into $Y$ is a $Y$-valued random variable on $(X,2^X )$. In particular, $\mathbb{R}^X = \mathcal{L}^0(X, 2^X )$. If $X$ is finite, then any such function is a simple random variable on $(X,2^X )$. Example 1.3: Let $X$ and $Y$ be two metric spaces. If $x : X\to Y$ is continuous, then $x$ is a $Y $-valued random variable on $(X,\mathcal{B}(X))$. Indeed, continuity of $x$ implies that the inverse image of every open set in $Y$ under $x$ is open in $X$. So this is enough to conclude that $x$ is a $Y$-valued random variable. In particular, $\mathbf{C}(X) \subseteq \mathcal{L}^0(X,\mathcal{B}(X))$ Example: $x\in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$ implies $ax\in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma )$ for any real number $a$. $x + y \in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma )$ for any $x,y\in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$. Thus, $\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$ is a linear space under the usual (pointwise) addition and scalar multiplication operations. The set of all simple random variables on $(X,\Sigma) $ constitutes a linear subspace of this linear space, which is itself a linear $X$ subspace of $\mathbb{R}^X $ . If $X$ is a metric space, then $\mathbf{C}(X)$ is also a linear subspace of $\mathcal{L}^0(X,\mathcal{B}(X))$. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: The Distribution of a Random Variable
Convergence of Random Variables
posts.text: DefinitionsConverge in distribution: Let $Y$ be a metric space. For any sequence of $Y $-valued random variables $(x_m)$ and a $Y $-valued random variable $x$, we say that $x_m$ converges to $x$ in distribution, denoted $x_m\stackrel{D}\to x$, if $\mathbf{p}{x_m}\stackrel{w}{\to} \mathbf{p}_x$, where $\mathbf{p}{x_m}$ and $\mathbf{p}_x$ are the distributions of $x_m$ and $x$, respectively, $m = 1,2,\cdots$. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 2.1: Let $Y$ be a metric space. For any $Y $-valued random variables $x, x_1, x_2,\cdots$, we have $x_m \stackrel{D}\to x$ iff, $$\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x_m)\to \mathbb{E}(\phi\circ x)\ \mbox{ for every } \in\mathbf{CB}(Y).$$ Corollary 2.2: Let $Y$ be a metric space. For any $Y $-valued random variables $x, x_1,x_2,\cdots$, we have $x_m \stackrel{D}\to x$ iff, $$E(\phi\circ x_m) \to \mathbb{E}(\phi\circ x)$$ for every bounded and Lipschitz continuous real map $\phi$ on $Y$. Proposition 2.3: Let $Y$ be a metric space, and let $x, x_1, x_2,\cdots$ be $Y $-valued random variables on a common probability space. Then $$x_m\to_{a.s.} x\ \mbox{ implies } x_m \stackrel{D}{\to} x,$$ but not conversely. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Expectation as a Stieltjes Integral
posts.text: Propositions and TheoremsTheorem 2.1: Let $x$ be a random variable and $\varphi$ an $F_x$-integrable self-map on $\mathbb{R} $. If $\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x)$ exists, then $$\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x)=\int_X(\varphi\circ x)d\mathbf{p}=\int_\mathbb{R}\varphi d\mathbf{p}x=\int^\infty{-\infty}\varphi dF_x$$ Corollary 2.2: Let $x$ be a nonnegative random variable and $\varphi$ an $F_x$-integrable self-map on $\mathbb{R} $. If $\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x)$ exists, then $$\mathbb{\varphi\circ x}=\varphi(0)F_x(0)+\int^\infty_0\varphi dF_x$$ Corollary 2.3: Let $x$ be a random variable with a continuously differentiable distribution function $F_x$, and $f$ a density function for $F_x$. Let $\varphi$ be an almost everywhere continuous and locally bounded self-map on $\mathbb{R} $. If $\varphi$ is $F_x$-integrable and $\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x)$ exists, then $$\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x)=\int^\infty_{-\infty}\varphi dF_x=\int^\infty_{-\infty}\varphi(t)f(t)dt$$ In particular, above equation holds for every continuous $\varphi : \mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}_+$. Moreover, if $\mathbb{E}(x)$ exists,$$\mathbb{E}(x)=\int_Xxd\mathbf{p}=\int^\infty_{-\infty}tdF_x(t)=\int^\infty_{-\infty}tf(t)dt$$ Proposition 2.4: Let $f : \mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}_+$ be a Borel measurable function. If $f$ is Riemann integrable, then $$\int_{\mathbb{R}}fd\ell=\int^\infty_{-\infty}f(t)dt$$ In particular, above equation holds when $f$ is bounded and continuous almost everywhere. Corollary 2.5: Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers with $a < b$. If $f : \mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}_+$ is Borel measurable and Riemann integrable (or bounded and continuous almost everywhere), then $$\int_{[a,b]}fd\ell=\int^b_af(t)dt$$ Similarly, we have$$\int_{(-\infty,a]}fd\ell=\int^a_{-\infty}f(t)dt, \ \ \ and \ \ \ \int_{[b,\infty)}fd\ell=\int^\infty_bf(t)dt$$ The Riemann and Lebesgue integrals of a Riemann integrable and nonnegative Borel measurable real function (defined on an interval) are equal. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Integration By Parts
posts.text: Propositions and TheoremsIntegration by Parts Formula: (Stieltjes) Let $F$ and $\varphi$ be two increasing real functions on $[a,b]$. If $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable, then $F$ is $\varphi$-integrable, and $$\int^b_a\varphi dF=\varphi(b)F(b)-\varphi(a)F(a)-\int^b_aFd\varphi$$ Proposition 3.1: Let $x$ be a nonnegative random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. If $\varphi$ is an increasing and $F_x$-integrable self-map on $\mathbb{R} $, then $$\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x)=\varphi(0)+\int^\infty_0(1-F_x)d\varphi$$ In particular,$$\mathbb{E}(x)=\int^\infty_0(1-F_x(t))dt$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Weak Convergence
posts.text: DefinitionsConverge Weakly, Weak Limit: Let $X$ be a metric space and $(\mathbf{p}_m)$ a sequence in $\Delta(X)$. For any $\mathbf{p}\in \Delta(X)$, we say that $(\mathbf{p}_m)$ converges weakly to $\mathbf{p}$, denoted $\mathbf{p}_m \stackrel{w}{\to} \mathbf{p}$, if $$\int_X\varphi d\mathbf{p}_m\to\int_X\varphi d\mathbf{p}\ \ \mbox{ for every } \varphi\in\mathbf{CB}(X)$$ In this case $\mathbf{p}$ is said to be the weak limit of $(\mathbf{p}_m)$. Put differently, we have$$\mathbf{p}m \stackrel{w}{\to} \mathbf{p} \mbox{ iff }\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{p}_m}(x)\to\mathbb{E}_\mathbf{p}(x)$$ for every $x\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\mathcal{B}(X))$. Converge Weakly, Weak Limit: The Lebesgue-Stieltjes measure induced by a distribution function $F$ is denoted by $\mathbf{p}_F$. And the class of all distribution functions is denoted by $\mathfrak{F}$. For any distribution functions $F, F_1, F_2,\cdots$, if $F_m(t)\to F(t)$ holds for every $t$ at which $F$ is continuous, we say the sequence $(F_m)$ weakly converges to an $F\in\mathfrak{F}$. $F$ is said to be the weak limit of $(F_m)$. Naturally enough, we denote this situation by writing $F_m\stackrel{w}\to F$. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 1.1: Let $X$ be a metric space and ($\mathbf{p}_m$) a sequence in $\Delta(X)$. If $\mathbf{p}_m \stackrel{w}{\to} \mathbf{p}$ and $\mathbf{p}_m\stackrel{w}{\to} \mathbf{q} $ for some $\mathbf{p},\mathbf{q}\in\Delta(X)$, then $\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{q}$. Corollary 1.2: Given any metric space $X$ and $\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}\in \Delta(X)$, we have $$\int_X\varphi d\mathbf{p}=\int_X\varphi d\mathbf{q}\ \mbox{ for all } \varphi\in\mathbf{CB}(X),\ \mbox{ iff } \mathbf{p}=\mathbf{q}$$ If two Borel probability measures are distinct, then the expectations of at least one continuous and bounded random variable with respect to these measures are not equal. Proposition 1.7: For any distribution functions $F, F_1, F_2,\cdots$, we have $\mathbf{p}_{F_m}\stackrel{w}{\to} \mathbf{p}_F$ iff $F_m\stackrel{w}\to F$. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: The Stieltjes Integral
posts.text: DefinitionsDissection, Subinterval, Division Point, Mesh: For two arbitrarily fixed real numbers $a$ and $b$ with $a < b$, for any positive integer $m$ and real numbers $a_0,\cdots,a_m$ with $a=a_0 <\cdots <a_m =b$, we refer to the collection$${[a_0,a_1], [a_1, a_2],\cdots, [a_{m-1},a_m]}$$ as a dissection of $[a,b]$, and denote it by either $\mathbf{a}$ or $[a_0,\cdots,a_m]$. Any one of the intervals $[a_{i-1},a_i] $ is called a subinterval of $\mathbf{a}$, while any one of $a_i$s is called a division point of $\mathbf{a}$. The maximum value of the lengths of its subintervals is called the mesh of $\mathbf{a}$-this value is denoted by $\mbox{mesh}(\mathbf{a})$. The collection of all dissections of $[a, b]$ is denoted as $\mathcal{D}[a, b]$. Finer than: For any dissections $\mathbf{a} = [a_0,\cdots,a_m]$ and $\mathbf{b} = [b_0,\cdots, b_k]$ of $[a, b]$, we write $$\mathbf{a}\Cup\mathbf{b}$$ for the dissection $[c_0,\cdots, c_l]$ in $\mathcal{D}[a, b]$ where ${c_0,\cdots, c_l} = {a_0,\cdots, a_m}\cup{b_0,\cdots, b_k}$. Moreover, we say that $\mathbf{b}$ is finer than $\mathbf{a}$ if ${a_0,\cdots, a_m} \subseteq {b_0,\cdots, b_k}$. Evidently, $\mathbf{a}\Cup \mathbf{b} = \mathbf{b}$ iff $\mathbf{b}$ is finer than $\mathbf{a}$. We also have $\mbox{mesh}(\mathbf{b})\leq \mbox{mesh}(\mathbf{a})$ if $\mathbf{b}$ is finer than $\mathbf{a}$, but not conversely. Darboux Sum: Take any bounded real functions $\varphi$ and $F$ on $[a, b]$ with $F$ being increasing. For any dissection $\mathbf{a} = [a_0,\cdots, a_m]$ of $[a, b]$, we define $$\check{\varphi}{\mathbf{a}}(i):=\sup{\varphi(t):a{i-1}\leq t\leq a_i}$$ and$$\hat{\varphi}{\mathbf{a}}(i):=\inf{\varphi(t):a{i-1}\leq t\leq a_i}$$ for each $i\in [m]$. (Since $\varphi$ is bounded, every one of these numbers is real.) By a Darboux sum of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$ and $\mathbf{a}$, we mean a number like$$\sum_{i\in[m]}\alpha_i(F(a_i)-F(a_{i-1}))$$ where $\hat{\varphi}_{\mathbf{a}} (i)\leq \alpha_i\leq \check{\varphi}_{\mathbf{a}}(i)$ for each $i$. In particular, the $\mathbf{a}$-upper Darboux sum of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$ is defined as the number$$\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi):=\sum{i\in[m]}\check{\varphi}_{\mathbf{a}}(i)(F(a_i)-F(a_{i-1}))$$ and the $\mathbf{a}$-lower Darboux sum of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$ is defined dually as$$\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi):=\sum{i\in[m]}\hat{\varphi}_{\mathbf{a}}(i)(F(a_i)-F(a_{i-1}))$$ Clearly, $\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi)$ decreases, and $\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi)$ increases, as a becomes finer. Evidently, we always have $\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi)\geq\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi) $. Furthermore, and this is important, we have$$\inf{\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi):\mathbf{a}\in\mathcal{D}[a,b]}\geq\sup{\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi):\mathbf{a}\in\mathcal{D}[a,b]}$$ The number on the left-hand side of this inequality is called the upper Stieltjes integral of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$, and is denoted by $\mathcal{S}_F (\varphi)$. Similarly, the number on the right-hand side is called the lower Stieltjes integrals of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$, and is denoted by $\mathbf{s}_F (\varphi)$. Thus, our inequality reads:$$\mathcal{S}_F (\varphi)\geq\mathbf{s}_F (\varphi)$$ Stiltjes Integrals, Stieltjes Integrable, $F$-integrable: Let $\varphi,F\in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ and assume that $F$ is increasing. Suppose that there exists a real number $\theta $ such that, for any $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists a dissection $\mathbf{a}$ of $[a, b]$ with $$|\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi)-\theta|<\varepsilon\mbox{ and }|\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi)-\theta|< \varepsilon$$ Then this number $\theta$ is unique, and it is denoted by$$\int^b_a\varphi dF\mbox{ or }\int^b_a\varphi(t)dF(t)$$ When it exists, we refer to this number as the Stieltjes integral of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$, and in that case, we say that $\varphi$ is Stieltjes integrable with respect to $F$, or simply, $F$-integrable. If , $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable, we also define$$\int^a_b\varphi dF=-\int^b_a\varphi dF$$ Finally, where $a\leq c\leq  d\leq  b$, we say that $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable on $[c,d]$, if $\varphi|{[c,d]}$ is $F|{[c,d]}$-integrable. $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable iff the upper and lower Stieltjes integrals of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$ are equal, that is,$$\inf{\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi) :\mathbf{a}\in\mathcal{D}[a, b]} = \sup{\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi) : \mathbf{a} \in \mathcal{D}[a, b]}$$ The following statements are equivalent: $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable, $\mathbf{S}_F(\varphi) = \mathbf{s}_F(\varphi)$, For every $\varepsilon > 0$, there is a dissection $\mathbf{a}\in \mathcal{D}[a, b]$ such that$$\mathbf{S}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi) -\mathbf{s}{F,\mathbf{a}}(\varphi)<\varepsilon$$ Riemman Integrable, Riemann Intergral: The Riemann integral is a special case of the Stieltjes integral. Formally, we say that $\varphi\in \mathbb{R}^{[a,b]}$ is Riemann integrable if it is $\mbox{id}_{[a,b]}$-integrable, and for any such $\varphi$, we define the Riemann integral of $\varphi$, denoted by $$\int^b_a\varphi(t)dt$$ as the Stieltjes integral of $\varphi$ with respect to the identity function on $[a, b]$. Continuous almost everywhere: Let us agree to call a real map $\varphi$ on $[a,b]$ continuous almost everywhere on $[a, b]$ if $$d(\varphi):={t\in[a,b]:\varphi\mbox{ is not continuous at }t}$$ is a “small” set in the following sense: For every $\varepsilon > 0$ there is an open subset $O$ of $[a,b]$ such that $ d(\varphi)\subseteq O$ and $\ell(O) <\varepsilon$. The totality of discontinuity points $\varphi$ fits within an open set of arbitrarily Lebesgue measure. $F$-integrable, Improper Stieltjes Integral, Riemann Integrable: Let $\varphi$ and $F$ be any two self-maps on $\mathbb{R} $, and assume that $F$ is increasing. Given any real numbers $a$ and $b$ with $a \leq b$, we say that $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable on $[a,b]$, if $\varphi$ is bounded on $[a,b]$ and $\int^b_a\varphi dF$ exists. (Note. If $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable on $[a,b]$, then $\int^b_a\varphi dF$ is a real number.) In turn, we say that $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable on $[a,\infty)$ if $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable on $[a,b]$ for each $b\geq a$, and $\lim_{b\to \infty}\int^b_a\varphi dF\in \overline{\mathbb{R} }$ In this case we define the (improper) Stieltjes integral of $\varphi$ with respect to $F$ on this unbounded interval as$$\int^\infty_a\varphi dF:=\lim_{c\to \infty}\int^c_a\varphi dF.$$ The $F $-integrability of $\varphi$ on $(-\infty,a]$ and the extended real number $\int^a_{-\infty}\varphi dF$ is analogously defined. Finally, we say that $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable, if there exists a real number a such that $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable on both $(-\infty,a]$ and $[a,\infty)$, and the expression $\int^a_\infty \varphi dF+\int^\infty_a\varphi dF$ is not of the indeterminate form $\infty-\infty$. In this case, we define$$\int^\infty_{-\infty}\varphi dF:=\int^a_{-\infty}\varphi dF+\int^\infty_{a}\varphi dF,$$ and note that this definition allows $\int^\infty_{-\infty}\varphi dF$ to equal $-\infty$ or $\infty$. If $\varphi$ is $id_{\mathbb{R} }$-integrable, then we say that it is Riemann integrable. The $F $-integrability of $\varphi$ implies that, on every compact interval, $\varphi$ is $F $-integrable. In particular, such a $\varphi$ is bounded on every compact interval. A self-map on $\mathbb{R} $ with this property is said to be locally bounded. Continous Almost Everywhere: The notion of almost everywhere continuity is extended to self-maps on $\mathbb{R} $ in the obvious way. Put precisely, we say that $\varphi$ is continuous almost everywhere (or almost everywhere continuous) if, for every $\varepsilon > 0$, there is an open subset $O$ of $\mathbb{R} $ such that $\ell(O) < \varepsilon$ and every point of discontinuity of $\varphi$ is contained in $O$. Obviously, if $\varphi$ is continuous almost everywhere, then it is continuous almost everywhere on any compact interval. Density, Density Function: We say that a distribution function $F$ has density, if there exists an almost everywhere continuous map $f : \mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}_+$ such that $f$ is locally bounded and $$F(s)=\int^s_{-\infty}f(t)dt$$ for every real number $s$. In this case, we say that $f$ is a density function for $F$. Propositions and TheoremsLemma 1.1: Let $\varphi,\ F\in \mathbf{B}[a,b]$ be such that $F$ is increasing. If $\varphi$ is $F$-integrable, then, $$\int^b_a\varphi dF=\int^c_a\varphi dF+\int^b_c\varphi dF,\ \ \ \ a\leq c\leq b$$ The same conclusion also holds if $\varphi$ is $F $-integrable on both $[a, c]$ and $[c, b]$. The Stieltjes integral is additive with respect to the interval of integration. Lemma 1.2: Assume $a < b$, and take any $\varphi, F\in \mathbf{B}[a,b]$ with $F$ being increasing. If $F$ is continuous and $\varphi$ is $F $-integrable. Then, $$\int^{\frac{b-1}{m}}_a\varphi dF\to\int^b_a\varphi dF\ \ \ and\ \ \ \ \int^b_{\frac{a+1}{m}}\varphi dF\to\int^b_a\varphi dF$$ When the integrator is a continuous function, altering the value of an integrable function at a single point does not alter the value of its integral Lemma 1.3: Let $\varphi,\ F\in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ be such that $F$ is increasing and $\varphi$ is $F $-integrable. If $\varphi\geq 0$ almost everywhere on $[a, b]$, then $$\int^b_a\varphi dF\geq0$$ Corollary 1.4: Let $\varphi, F \in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ be such that $F$ is increasing and $\varphi$ is $F $-integrable. If $\varphi$ vanishes almost everywhere on $[a,b]$, then $$\int^b_a\varphi dF=0$$ Lemma 1.5: Let $\varphi, F \in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ be such that $F$ is increasing, and both $\varphi$ and $\phi$ are $F$-integrable. Then, for any real number $\alpha$, we have $$\int^b_a(\alpha\varphi+\phi)dF=\alpha\int^b_a\varphi dF+\int^b_a\phi dF$$ The Stieltjes integral is linear with respect to its integrand. Proposition 1.6: (Stieltjes) Take any $\varphi, F\in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ with $F$ being increasing. If $\varphi$ is continuous, then it is $F$-integrable. Proposition 1.7: Let $\varphi, F \in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ and assume that $F$ is increasing and Lipschitz continuous. If $\varphi$ is continuous almost everywhere on $[a,b]$, then it is $F $-integrable. The Lebesgue Criterion: If $\varphi \in \mathbf{B}[a,b]$ is continuous almost everywhere on $[a,b] $, then it is Riemann integrable. Riemann integrability = Continuity almost everywhere. Corollary 1.8: Let $\varphi\in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ be continuous almost everywhere on $[a, b]$. If $\varphi$ vanishes almost everywhere on $[a, b]$, then $$\int^b_a\varphi(t)dt=0$$ The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus 1: Let $f \in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ be continuous almost everywhere and $F\in \mathbb{R}^{[a,b]}$ satisfy $$F(s)=F(a)+\int^s_af(r)dr,\ \ \ \ a\leq s\leq b$$ Then, $F$ is Lipschitz continuous on $[a,b]$, and for every $s\in [a,b]$ at which $f$ is continuous, $F’(s)$ exists and equals $f(s)$. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus 2: Take any $F\in \mathbf{C}^1[a,b]$, and let $f \in \mathbf{B}[a,b]$ is a Riemann integrable function such that $F’ = f$ almost everywhere on $[a, b]$. Then we have$$F(s)=F(a)+\int^s_af(r)dr,\ \ \ \ a\leq s\leq b$$ Roughly speaking, The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus says that we can think of dif ferentiation and Riemann integration as inverse operations. Theorem 1.10: Let $\varphi\in \mathbf{B}[a, b]$ be continuous almost everywhere on $[a, b]$. Then, for any increasing $F\in \mathbf{C}^1[a,b]$, we have $$\int^b_a\varphi dF=\int^b_a\varphi(t)F’(t)dt$$ Corollary 1.11: Let $f,\varphi\in \mathbf{B}[a,b]$ be continuous almost everywhere on $[a,b]$ and assume $f \geq 0$. Then, for any $F\in \mathbf{C}^1[a, b]$ such that$$F(s)=F(a)+\int^s_af(r)dr,\ \ \ \ a\leq s\leq b$$ holds, we have $$\int^b_a\varphi dF=\int^b_a\varphi(t)f(t)dt$$ Theorem 1.10 and Corollary 1.11 help to reduce a Stieltjes Integral to a Riemann Integral, gaining computational power. Proposition 1.12: Let $\varphi$ and $F$ be two self-maps on $\mathbb{R} $, and assume that $F$ is increasing and continuously differentiable. If $\varphi$ is nonnegative, locally bounded, and continuous almost everywhere, then it is $F $-integrable. Theorem 1.13: Let $F\in \mathbf{C}^1(\mathbb{R} )$ be a distribution function, and $\varphi$ a locally bounded self-map on $\mathbb{R} $ that is continuous almost everywhere. If $f$ is a density function for $F $, then $$\int^\infty_{-\infty}\varphi dF=\int^\infty_{-\infty}\varphi(t)f(t)dt$$ in the sense that if one side exists so does the other. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Elements of Abstract Algebra
posts.text:
DefinitionsBinary Operation A binary operation on a set $G$ is a function $$∗ : G ×G → G$$ As with any function, a binary operation is well-defined; when one says this explicitly, it is usually called the law of substitution: If $x = x’$ and $y = y’$, then $x ∗ y = x’ ∗ y’$. Group A group is a set $G$ equipped with a binary operation $∗$ such that the associative law holds: for every $x, y, z ∈ G$, $x ∗ (y ∗ z) = (x ∗ y) ∗ z$ there is an element $e∈G$, called the identity, with $e∗x=x=x∗e$ for all $x∈G$ every $x∈G$ has an inverse; there is $x’∈G$ with $x∗x’=e=x’∗x$. Abelian Group A group $G$ is called abelian if it satisfies the commutative law: $x∗y=y∗x$ holds for every x, y ∈ G. We will usually denote the product $x ∗ y$ in a group by $xy$, and we will denote the identity by $1$ instead of by $e$. When a group is abelian, however, we will often use the additive notation $x + y$; in this case, we will denote the identity by $0$, and we will denote the inverse of an element $x$ by $−x$ instead of by $x^{−1}$. Ring: A ring $(R, +, ·)$ is an abelian group $(R, +)$ endowed with a second binary operation $·$, satisfying on its own the requirements of being associative and having a two-sided identity and further interacting with $+$ via the distributive properties:, i.e., $∀r,s,t∈R$, $(r·s)·t=r·(s·t)$, $∃1_R ∈ R, ∀r ∈ R$, $r · 1_R = r = 1_R · r$ $∀r,s,t∈R$, $(r+s)·t=r·s+r·t$ and $t·(r+s)=t·r+t·s$. What we are calling a ring, others may call a ring with identity or a ring with 1: it is not uncommon to exclude the axiom of existence of a multiplicative identity from the list of axioms defining a ring. Commutative Ring A commutative ring $R$ is a set with two binary operations, addition and multiplication, such that $R$ is an abelian group under addition; (commutativity) $ab = ba$ for all $a, b ∈ R$; (associativity) $a(bc) = (ab)c$ for every $a,b, c ∈ R$; there is an element $1∈R$ with $1a=a$ for every $a∈R$; (distributivity) $a(b + c) = ab + ac$ for every $a, b, c ∈ R$. Subring A subset S of a commutative ring R is a subring of R if $1 ∈ S$; if $a,b∈S$, then $a−b∈S$; if $a,b∈S$, then $ab∈S$. Domain / Integral Domain A domain / Integral domain is a commutative ring $R$ that satisfies two extra axioms: $1
eq 0$; The cancellation law for multiplication: For all $a, b, c ∈ R$, if $ca = cb$ and $c
eq 0$, then $a = b$. Divide: Let $a$ and $b$ be elements of a commutative ring $R$. Then $a$ divides $b$ in $R$ (or $a$ is a divisor of $b$ or $b$ is a multiple of $a$), denoted by $a | b$, if there exists an element $c ∈ R$ with $b = ca$. Unit, Inverse: An element $u$ in a commutative ring $R$ is called a unit if $u | 1$ in $R$ that is, if there exists $v ∈ R$ with $uv = 1$; the element $v$ is called the inverse of $u$ and $v$ is often denoted by $u^{−1}$. Group of Units: If $R$ is a commutative ring, then the group of units of $R$ is $U(R) = {\mbox{all units in }R}$. Field: A field $F$ is a commutative ring in which $1
eq 0$ and every nonzero element $a$ is a unit; that is, there is $a^{−1} ∈ F$ with $a^{−1}a = 1$. Subfield: A subfield of a field $K$ is a subring $k$ of $K$ that is also a field. Propositions and TheoremsLemma 2.16. Let G be a group. The cancellation laws hold: If either $x∗a=x∗b$ or $a∗x=b∗x$, then $a=b$. The element $e$ is the unique element in $G$ with $e∗x=x=x∗e$ for all $x∈G$. Each $x ∈ G$ has a unique inverse: There is only one element $x’∈ G$ with $x ∗ x’ = e = x′ ∗ x$ (henceforth, this element will be denoted by $x^{−1}$). $(x^{-1})^{−1} = x$ for all $x ∈ G$. Proposition 3.2. Let $R$ be a commutative ring. $0·a=0$ for every $a∈R$. If $1 = 0,$ then $R$ consists of the single element $0$. In this case, $R$ is called the zero ring. If $−a$ is the additive inverse of $a$, then $(−1)(−a) = a$. $(−1)a = −a$ for every $a ∈ R$. If $n∈N$ and $n1=0$, then $na=0$ for all $a∈R$. Proposition 3.3. A subring $S$ of a commutative ring $R$ is itself a commutative ring. Reference John Boller and Paul J. Sally, Jr., “A Textbook for Advanced Calculus”; Paolo Aluffi, 2009, “Algebra: Chapter 0”; Michael Artin, 2010, “Algebra”; Joseph J. Rotman, 2003, “Advanced Modern Algebra”;

posts.title: Independence of Collection of Events
posts.text: DefinitionsIndependence of Events: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probability space. The events $A,B\in\Sigma$ are said to be (stochastically) independent if $\mathbf{p}(A \cap B) = \mathbf{p}(A)\mathbf{p}(B)$. If $A = B$ here, we say that $A$ is independent of itself. In turn, a nonempty collection $\mathcal{A}\subseteq \Sigma$ is called independent – we denote this by writing $\coprod \mathcal{A}$ – if$$\mathbf{p}(\bigcap \mathcal{S})=\prod_{A\in\mathcal{S}}\mathbf{p}(A)$$ for every nonempty finite subset $\mathcal{S}$ of $\mathcal{A}$. Independence of Finitely Many Familites of Events: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probability space and $m$ an integrer with $m>1$. The nonempty collection $\mathcal{A}_1,\cdots,\mathcal{A}_m\subseteq \Sigma$ are said to be (stochastically) independent – we denote this by writing $\coprod [\mathcal{A}_1,\dots,\mathcal{A}_m]$ – if$$\coprod {A_1,\dots,A_m}\mbox{ for every }(A_1,\dotsm,A_m)\in\mathcal{A}_1\times\cdots\times\mathcal{A}_m$$ The definition of independence of events is a special case of that of independence of collections of events. Independence of Infinitely Many Familites of Events: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probability space, $I$ any (index) set with $|I|>1$, and $\mathcal{A}_i$ a nonempty subset of $\Sigma$ for each $i\in I$. We say that $\mathcal{A}_i$s are independent – we denote this by writing $\coprod [\mathcal{A}i, i\in I]$ – if $\coprod [\mathcal{A}{i_1},\dots,\mathcal{A}_{i_m}]$ for every integrer with $m>1$ and every distinct $i_1,\dots,i_m\in I$. If $I=\mathbb{N}$ here, we write $\coprod[\mathcal{A}_1,\mathcal{A}_2,\dots]$ to denote $\coprod[\mathcal{A}_i:i\in I]$. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 1.1: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probabilty space, and $m$ an integer with $m > 1$. If $\mathcal{A}i\subseteq\Sigma$ contains $X$ for each $i\in[m]$, then $\coprod [\mathcal{A}_1,\dots,\mathcal{A}_m]$ iff$$\mathbf{p}\left(\bigcap{i\in[m]}A_i\right)=\prod_{i\in[m]}\mathbf{p}(A_i)\mbox{ for every }(A_1,\dotsm,A_m)\in\mathcal{A}_1\times\cdots\times\mathcal{A}_m$$ Proposition 1.2: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probabilty space, and $m$ an integer with $m > 1$. If $\mathcal{A}_i\subseteq\Sigma$ contains $X$, and is closed under taking finite intersections, for each $i\in[m]$, then$$\coprod [\mathcal{A}_1,\dots,\mathcal{A}_m]\mbox{ implies }\coprod [\sigma(\mathcal{A}_1),\dots,\sigma(\mathcal{A}_m)]$$ Proposition 1.3: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probabilty space, $I$ any (index) set with $|I|>1$, and $\mathcal{A}_i$ a nonempty subset of $\Sigma$ for each $i\in I$. If $\mathcal{A}_i\subseteq\Sigma$ contains $X$, and is closed under taking finite intersections, for each $i\in[m]$, then$$\coprod[\mathcal{A}_i:i\in I]\mbox{ implies }\coprod[\sigma(\mathcal{A}_i):i\in I]$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Independence of Random Variables
posts.text: DefinitionsIndependence of Random Variables: For any positive integer $i$, let $Y_i$ be a metric space and $x_i$ a $Y_i$-valued random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. For any $m > 1$, we say that $x_1,\dots,x_m$ are (stochastically) independent when $(x_1),\dots,(x_m)$ are independent, that is,$$\mathbf{p}\left(\bigcap_{i\in[m]}{x_i\in A_i}\right)=\prod_{i\in[m]}\mathbf{p}{x_i\in A_i}\mbox{ for every }A_i\in\mathcal{B}(Y_i),\ i=1,\dots,m$$ and we denote this situation by writting $\coprod [x_1,\dots,x_m]$ If $\coprod [x,x]$ for any $Y$-valued random variable $x$ on $(x,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, we say that $x$ is independent of itself. More generally, if $\coprod [\sigma(x_1),\sigma(x_2),\dots]$ we say that $x_1,x_2,\dots$ are independent or $(x_m)$ is a sequence of independent of random variables, and write $\coprod [x_1,x_2,\dots]$ Uncorrelated: Let $x$ and $y$ be two integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. Clearly, $xy$ is also a random variable on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ We say that $x$ and $y$ are uncorrelated if $\mathbb{E}(xy) = \mathbb{E}(x)\mathbb{E}(y)$. Independently and Identically Distributed Random Variables: Let $Y$ be a metric space, and $(x_m)$ a sequence of $Y$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. For any $m > 1$, we say that $x_1,\dots, x_m$ are independently and identically distributed, or simply i.i.d., if $\coprod [x_1,\dots,x_m]$ and $\mathbf{p}_{x_i} = \mathbf{p}_{x_j}$ for every $i,j\in[m]$. More generally, we say that $x_1,x_2,\dots$ are i.i.d. (or that $(x_m)$ is a sequence of i.i.d. random variables when $\coprod [x_1,\dots,x_m]$ and $\mathbf{p}_{x_i} = \mathbf{p}_{x_j}$ for every postive integers $i$ and $j$. If $Y=\mathbb{R}$, then $\mathbf{p}_{x_i} = \mathbf{p}_{x_j}$ implies they have the same distribution and distribution functions. Take the normal distribution as an example, the $\mu$ and $\sigma$ should be the same for all i.i.d. random variables. Propositions and TheoremsProposition 2.1: Let $m$ be a positive integer, and $x_1,\dots,x_m$ integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. Then,$$\coprod [x_1,\dots,x_m]\mbox{ implies }\mathbb{E}\left(\prod_{i\in[m]}x_i\right)=\prod_{i\in[m]}\mathbb{E}(x_i)$$ The expectation of the product of a finite number of independent random variables (each with finite expectation) equals the product of the expectations of these random variables. In particular, any two independent random variables are uncorrelated. Proposition 2.2: Let $m$ be a positive integer, and $x_1,\dots,x_m$ random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$. Then, $\coprod [x_1,\dots,x_m]$ iff$$F_{x_1,\dots,x_m}(a_1,\dots,a_m)=\prod_{i\in[m]}F_{x_i}(a_i)\mbox{ for every }(a_1,\dots,a_m)\in\mathbb{R}^m.$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Law of Large Numbers
posts.text: DefinitionsRandom Sample, Statistic: Let $x$ be a random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. A random sample for $x$ is a finite collection $x_1,\dots,x_m$ of i.i.d. random variables on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $x_1 =_{a.s.} x$. A (real-valued) statistic based on such a random sample is a random variable of the form $\varphi(x_1,\dots, x_m)$, where $\varphi$ is a Borel measurable real function on $\mathbb{R}\cup \mathbb{R}^2\cdots $ Notice that $\varphi$ can accomodate any random sample regardless of its size. Unbiased estimator: The statistics based on a random sample are used to derive inferences about the characteristics of the random variable of interest. We would then surely wish them to satisfy certain properties.
