For instance, a desirable property in this regard is that of unbiasedness: We say that a statistic $\varphi(x_1,\dots,x_m)$ based on the random sample $x_1,\dots, x_m$ is an unbiased estimator of $x$ if$$\mathbb{E}(\varphi(x_1,\dots,x_m))=\theta_x$$ where $\theta_x$ is a characteristic of $x$, such as its mean or another moment. The property of unbiasedness is well-defined for any random sample, regardless of its size. As such, it is said to be a small-sample property. Consistent estimator, Strongly consistent esitimator: We say that a statistic $\varphi(x_1,\dots,x_m)$ based on the random sample $x_1,\dots, x_m$ is a consistent estimator of a characteristic $\theta_x$ of $x$ if$$\mathbf{p}\mbox{-}\lim\varphi(x_1,\dots,x_m)=\theta_x$$And that it is a strongly consistent estimator of $\theta_x$ if$$\mathbf{p}{\varphi(x_1,\dots,x_m)\to\theta_x}=1$$ A large-sample property of a statistic would instead be based on the limiting properties of this statistic as the sample size gets large. Of particular interest in this regard are the properties of consistency. Propositions and TheoremsThe Weak Law of Large Numbers: (Chebyshev) Let $(x_m)$ be a sequence of independent random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ with $\mathbb{E}(x_1) = \mathbb{E}(x_2) = \cdots\in \mathbb{R}$ and $\sup \mathbb{V}(x_m) < \infty$. Then,$$\mathbb{E}\left(\left|\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i-\mathbb{E}(x_1)\right|\right)\to 0\mbox{ and }\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to\mathbb{E}(x_1)\mbox{ in probability}$$ Corollary 2.1: Let $(x_m)$ be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables with finite expectation and variance. Then,$$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to\mathbb{E}(x_1)\mbox{ in probability}$$ Khinchine’s Weak Law of Large Numbers: Let $(x_m)$ be a sequence of i.i.d. random variables with finite expectation. Then, $$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to\mathbb{E}(x_1)\mbox{ in probability}$$ Markov’s Weak Law of Large Numbers: Let $(x_m)$ be a sequence of uncorrelated random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $\sup\mathbb{E}(x_m) < 1$ and $\sup \mathbb{V}_(x_m) < 1$. Assume further that$$\lim\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\mathbb{E}(x_i)\in\mathbb{R}\mbox{ and }\frac{1}{m^2}\sum_{i\in[m]}\mathbb{V}(x_i)\to0$$ Then$$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to\lim\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\mathbb{E}(x_i)\mbox{ in probability}$$ The Strong Law of Large Numbers: (Kolmogorov) For any sequence $(x_m)$ of integrable i.i.d. random variables, we have$$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to_{a.s.}\mathbb{E}(x_1)$$ Corollary 2.2: (Kolmogorov) For any sequence $(x_m)$ of integrable i.i.d. random variables such that $\mathbb{E}(x_1)\in{-\infty,\infty}$, we have$$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to_{a.s.}\mathbb{E}(x_1)$$ Examples and ExercisesSample Mean, Sample Variance: For a random sample with a finite collection $a_1,\dots,a_m$ of i.i.d. random variables on $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ such that $a_1 =_{a.s.} a$. If$$\varphi(a_1,\dots,a_m):=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}a_i$$Then $\varphi(a_1,\dots,a_m)$ corresponds to the statistic of the sample mean If$$\varphi(a_1,\dots,a_m):=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\left(a_i-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}a_i\right)^2$$Then $\varphi(a_1,\dots,a_m)$ corresponds to the statistic of the sample variance. Sample mean is an unbiased estimator of $\mathbb{E}(x)$, for any postive integer $m$.$$\mathbb{E}\left(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\right)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\mathbbE=\mathbb{E}(x)$$as $\mathbb{E}(x_i) = \mathbb{E}(x)$ for each $i$. By contrast, the sample variance is not an unbiased estimator of $\mathbb{V}(x)$. Example 2.2: The sample mean is a strongly consistent estimator of $\mathbb{E}(x)$ provided that $\mathbb{E}(x)$ is finite. This is the same thing as saying that$$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\to_{a.s.}\mathbb{E}(x)$$ when $\mathbb{E}(x)$ is finite. Example 2.3: The sample variance is a strongly consistent estimator of $\mathbb{V}(x)$ provided that both $\mathbb{E}(x)$ and $\mathbb{E}(x^2)$ are finite. This is the same thing as saying that$$\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\left(x_i-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}x_i\right)^2\to_{a.s.}\mathbb{V}(x)$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Conditional Expectation
posts.text: DefinitionsConditional Expectation on a Known Event: Let $x$ be an integrable random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ That is, $x\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma$) and $\mathbb{E}(|x|) < \infty$, or put differently, $x\in\mathcal{L}^1(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ For any event $C\in\Sigma$ with $\mathbf{p}(C) > 0$, the conditional expectation of $x$ given $C$ is defined as$$\mathbb{E}(x|C):=\frac{1}{\mathbf{p}(C)}\int_Cxd\mathbf{p}$$ When it is known that the event $C$ has occurred, one is less uncertain about the outcome of the underlying experiment. The relevant probability space in this case can be thought of as $(C,\Sigma\cap C,\mathbf{q})$, where $\Sigma\cap C := {A\cap C:A\in\Sigma}$ and$$\mathbf{q}:=\frac{1}{\mathbf{p}(C)}\mathbf{p}|_{\Sigma\cap C}$$Consequently, we compute the conditional expectation of $x$ given $C$ simply as the expectation of $x|_C$ on this space. Conditional Probability on a Known Event: The conditional probability of an event $A\in\Sigma$ given $C$ is $\mathbf{p}(A|C) := \frac{\mathbf{p}(A \cap C)}{\mathbf{p}(C)}$ Just as the probability of an event is the expectation of the indicator function of that event, the conditional probability of an event is the conditional expectation of the indicator function of that event:$$\mathbb{p}(A|C)=\frac{\mathbb{p}(A\cap C)}{\mathbf{p}(C)}\mathbb{E}(\mathbf{1}_A|C)$$Note that these notions apply only when we know that an event has already occurred. Countable (finite) $\Sigma$-decomposition: By a countable (finite) $\Sigma$-decomposition of $X$ we mean a countable (finite) partition $\mathcal{C}$ of $X$ such that $\mathcal{C}\subseteq \Sigma$ and $\mathbf{p}(C) > 0$ for all $C\in\mathcal{C}$. Conditional Expectation on a Countable Decomposition: We define the conditional expectation of $x$ given $\mathcal{C}$ as the discrete random variable $\mathbb{E}(x|{\mathcal{C}}) : X \to \mathbb{R}$ with$$\mathbb{E}(x|\mathcal{C})(\omega):=\mathbb{E}(x|C_\omega)$$or$$\int_{C_\omega}\mathbb{E}(x|\mathcal{C})d\mathbf{p}=\int_{C_\omega}xd\mathbf{p}\mbox{ for every }\omega\in X$$ where $C_\omega$ is the member of $\mathcal{C}$ that contains the outcome $\omega$. More compactly, we may write$$\mathbb{E}(x|\mathcal{C}):=\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}\mathbb{E}(x|C)\mathbf{1}_C$$ Given that we will observe which member of $\mathcal{C}$ has occurred once the experiment is performed, we then calculate the conditional expectation. A gambler, for instance, would like to have a strategy which is contingent on what will happen through the sequence of games she will repeatedly participate in. Conditional Probability on a Countable Decomposition: The conditional probability of an event $A$ in $\Sigma$ given $\mathcal{C}$ is similarly defined as the discrete random variable $\mathbf{p}(A|\mathcal{C}) : X\to\mathbb{R}$ with$$\mathbf{p}(A|\mathcal{C}) (\omega):=\frac{\mathbf{p}(A\cap C_\omega)}{\mathbf{p}(C_\omega)}$$ Or equivalently,$$\mathbf{p}(A|\mathcal{C}):=\sum_{C\in\mathcal{C}}\mathbf{p}(A\cap C)\mathbf{1}_C$$ Of course, we have $\mathbf{p}(A|\mathcal{C})=\mathbb{E}(\mathbf{1}_A|\mathcal{C})$ Sub-$\sigma$-algebra: Let $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ be a probability space. By a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$, we mean a subset of $\Sigma$ which is itself a $\sigma$-algebra. Conditional Expectation on an Arbitrary $\sigma$-algebra, Conditional Probability on an Arbitrary $\sigma$-algebra: For any sub-$\sigma$-algebra $\Sigma_0$ of $\Sigma$, and any $x\in\mathcal{L}^1(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, the conditional expectation of $x$ given $\Sigma_0$ is defined as an extended real function $\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$ on $X$ which satisfies$$\mathbb{E}(x | \Sigma_0)\mbox{ is }\Sigma_0\mbox{-measurable}$$ and$$\int_B\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)d\mathbf{p}=\int_Bxd\mathbf{p}\mbox{ for every }B\in\Sigma_0$$ For any $y \in \mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma)$ we define the conditional expectation of $x$ given $y$, denoted $\mathbb{E}(x| y)$ as $\mathbb{E}(x | y) := \mathbb{E}(x |\sigma (y))$ For any $A\in\Sigma$, we define the conditional probability of $A$ given $\Sigma_0$, denoted $\mathbf{p}(A|\Sigma_0)$ as an extended real function on $X$ that equals $\mathbb{E}(\mathbf{1}_A| \Sigma_0)$ or equivalently, that satisfies$$\mathbf{p}(x | \Sigma_0)\mbox{ is }\Sigma_0\mbox{-measurable}$$ and$$\int_B\mathbf{p}(x|\Sigma_0)d\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{p}(A\cap B)\mbox{ for every }B\in\Sigma_0$$ Conditional Density: Let $x$ and $y$ be two integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ and let $f$ be a joint density for $x$ and $y$ The conditional density of $x$ given $y$ is defined as$$f_{x|y}(s,t):=\left{\begin{matrix}\frac{f(s,t)}{f_y(t)}&\mbox{if }f_y(t)>0\0&\mbox{otherwise}\end{matrix}\right.$$ where $f_y$ is the marginal density of $y$. We can show that$$\mathbb{E}(x|y)={a.s.}\int^\infty{-\infty}sf_{x|y}(s,y(\cdot))ds$$ Propositions and TheoremsTherorem 1.1: If $x$ is an integrable random variable on the probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$, and $\Sigma_0$ is a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$, then $\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$ exists. Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Preliminaries of Probability Limit Theorems
posts.text: DefinitionsConverge in Probability: Let $Y$ be a separable metric space, and $x,x_1,x_2,\dots$ be $Y$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. We say that $(x_m)$ converges to $x$ in probability, and write $x_m\to x$ in probability, or $\mathbf{p}$-$\lim x_m = x$ if$$\mathbf{p}{d_Y(x_m,x)>\varepsilon}\to 0 \mbox{ for every }\varepsilon>0$$ That is, $x_m \to x$ in probability iff, for every positive real numbers $\varepsilon$ and $\delta$ there exists a positive integer $M$ such that$$\mathbf{p}{d_Y(x_m,x)>\varepsilon}<\delta \mbox{ for all }m>M$$ Propositions and TheoremsProposition 1.1： Let $Y$ be a separable metric space, and $x,x_1,x_2,\dots$ be $Y$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. If $(x_m)$ converges to $x$ in probability, then $x_m\stackrel{D}\to x$. Proposition 1.2: (Kolmogorov) Let $Y$ be a separable metric space, and $x,x_1,x_2,\dots$ be $Y$-valued random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$. If $x_m\to_{a.s.}x$, then $(x_m)$ converges to $x$ in probability. $$\mbox{almost sure convergence}\Longrightarrow\mbox{convergence in probability}\Longrightarrow\mbox{convergence in distribution}$$ Theorem 3.8: Let $Y$ be a separable metric space For any given real number $p\geq1$, let $x, x_1,x_2,\dots$ be $Y$-valued random variables on $\mathcal{L}^p(X,\Sigma,\mathbf{p})$ If $(x_m)$ is $\mathcal{L}^p$-convergent, then $(x_m)$ converges to $x$ in probability. $$\mathcal{L}^p\mbox{-convergence}\Longrightarrow\mbox{convergence in probability}\Longrightarrow\mbox{convergence in distribution}$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: Propertities of Conditional Expectation
posts.text: Propositions and TheoremsProposition 2.1: Let $x$ and $y$ be integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ and $\Sigma_0$ a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$. Then, for every real number $\alpha$$$\mathbb{E}(\alpha x|\Sigma_0)={a.s.}\alpha\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$$and$$\mathbb{E}(x+y|\Sigma_0)={a.s.}\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)+\mathbb{E}(y|\Sigma_0)$$ Moreover,$$x=_{a.s.}y\mbox{ implies }\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)+\mathbb{E}(y|\Sigma_0)$$ Proposition 2.2: Let $x$ and $y$ be integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ and $\Sigma_0$ a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$. Then,$$\mathbb{E}(\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0))=\mathbb{E}(x)$$And if $\Sigma_1$ is another sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$, then$$\Sigma_0\subseteq \Sigma_1\mbox{ implies }\mathbb{E}(\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_1)|\Sigma_0)=\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$$ Proposition 2.4: Let $x$ and $y$ be integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ and $\Sigma_0$ a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$. If $y\in\mathcal{L}^0(X,\Sigma_0)$ and $\mathbb{E}(|xy|)<\infty$,then$$\mathbb{E}(xy|\Sigma_0)=_{a.s.}y\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$$ The Conditional Monotone Convergence Theorem: Let $x, x_1,x_2,\dots$ be nonnegative integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ such that $x_m\nearrow_{a.s.} x$ If $\Sigma_0$ is a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$, then$$\mathbb{E}(x_m|\Sigma_0)\nearrow_{a.s.}\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$$ The Conditional Dominated Convergence Theorem: Let $x, y,x_1,x_2,\dots$ be nonnegative integrable random variables on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$ such that $x_m\leq_{a.s.} x$ for each $m$ If $\Sigma_0$ is a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$, then$$\mathbb{E}(x_m|\Sigma_0)\to_{a.s.}\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0)$$ The Conditional Jensen’s Inequality: Let $x$ be an integrable random variable on a probability space $(X,\Sigma, \mathbf{p})$, and $\Sigma_0$ a sub-$\sigma$-algebra of $\Sigma$. If $\varphi$ is a concave self-map on $\mathbb{R}$ such that $\mathbb{E}(|\varphi\circ x|) <\infty$, then$$\varphi(\mathbb{E}(x|\Sigma_0))\geq_{a.s.}\mathbb{E}(\varphi\circ x|\Sigma_0)$$ Reference Efe A. Ok, “Measure and Probability Theory with Economic Applications”; Lecture notes, ECON 30400 2, Autumn 2020, Introduction: Mathematical Methods In Economics; Walter Rudin, 1987, “Real and Complex Analysis”; Walter Rudin, 1976, “Principle of Mathematical Analysis”;

posts.title: The Nature of Dynamic Optimization
posts.text: Salient Features of Dynamic Optimization ProblemsDynamic optimization can be viewed as a problem of multistage decision making. The Discrete-Variable VersionSuppose that a firm engages in transforming a certain substance from an initial state $A$ (raw material state) into a termi­nal state $Z$ (finished product state) through a five-stage production process. In every stage, the firm faces the problem of choosing among several possible alternative subprocesses, each entailing a specific cost. The ques­tion is: How should the firm select the sequence of subprocesses through the five stages in order to minimize the total cost? In Fig. 1.1, our problem is transformed to choose a connected sequence of arcs going from left to right, starting at $A$ and terminating at $Z$, such that the sum of the values of the component arcs is minimized. The optimal solution for the present example is the path $ACEHJZ$, with $14 as the minimum cost of production. The Continuous-Variable VersionWe can visualize Fig. 1.2 to be a map of an open terrain, with the stage variable representing the longitude, and the state variable representing the latitude. Our assigned task is to transport a load of cargo from location $A$ to location $Z$ at minimum cost by selecting an appropriate travel path. The cost associated with each possible path de­pends, in general, not only on the distance traveled, but also on the topography on that path. Regardless of whether the variables are discrete or continuous, a simple type of dynamic optimization problem would contain the following basic ingredients: a given initial point and a given terminal point; a set of admissible paths from the initial point to the terminal point; a set of path values serving as performance indices (cost, profit, etc.) associated with the various paths; and a specified objective-either to maximize or to minimize the path value or performance index by choosing the optimal path. For most of the problems, the stage variable will represent time; then the optimal path is actually optimal time path. The Concept of a FunctionalThe relationship between paths and path values represents a special sort of mapping not a mapping from real numbers to real numbers as in the usual function but a mapping from paths (curves) to real numbers (performance indices). Let us denote time paths by $y_I(t), y_{II}(t)$, and so on. Then the mapping is as shown in Fig. 1.3, where $V_I$, $V_{II}$ represent the associated path values. The general notation for the mapping should there­ fore be $V[y(t)]$. But this symbol fundamentally differs from the composite-function symbol $g[f(x)]$. In the latter, $g$ is a function of $f$, and $f$ is in turn a function of $x$; thus, $g$ is in the final analysis a function of $x$. In the symbol $V[y(t)]$, on the other hand, the $y(t)$ component comes as an integral unit-to indicate time paths-and there­fore $V$ is actually a functional of $y(t)$ Variable Endpoints and Transversality ConditionsTypes of Variable Terminal PointsIn Fig. 1.5a, while the planning horizon is fixed at time $T$, any point on the vertical line $t = T$ is acceptable as a terminal point, such as $Z_1$, $Z_2$, and $Z_3$• This type of problem is commonly referred to in the literature as a fixed-time-horizon problem, fixed-time problem, or the vertical-terminal-line problem, meaning that the termi­nal time of the problem is fixed rather than free. In Fig. 1.5b, the horizontal line $y = Z$ constitutes the set of admissible terminal points. Each of these, depending on the path chosen, may be associated with a different terminal time, as exemplified by $T_1$, $T_2$, and $T_3$• This type of problem is commonly referred to as a fixed-endpoint problem, or the horizontal-terminal-line problem. In the third type, neither the termi­nal time $T$ nor the terminal state $Z$ is individually preset, but the two are tied together via a constraint equation of the form $Z = \phi(T)$, as illustrated in Fig. 1.5c. We shall call this type of problem the terminal-curve (or terminal-surface) problem . Transversality ConditionThe common feature of variable-terminal-point problems is that the planner has one more degree of freedom than in the fixed-terminal-point case. But this fact automatically implies that, in deriving the optimal solution, an extra condition is needed to pinpoint the exact path chosen. In the former, the optimal path must satisfy the boundary (initial and terminal) conditions$$y(0) =A\mbox{ and }y(T)=Z\ \ \ \ (T,A, \mbox{ and }Z \mbox{ all given})$$ In the latter case, the initial condition $y(O)=A$ still applies by assumption. But since $T$ and / or $Z$ are now variable, the terminal condition $y(T) = Z$ is no longer capable of pinpointing the optimal path for us. As Fig. 1.5 shows, all admissible paths, ending at $Z_1, Z_2$, or other possible terminal positions, equally satisfy the condition $y(T) = Z$. What is needed, therefore, is a terminal condition that can conclusively distinguish the optimal path from the other admissible paths. Such a condition is referred to as a transversal­ity condition, because it normally appears as a description of how the optimal path crosses the terminal line or the terminal curve (to “transverse” means to “to go across”). The Objective FunctionalThe Integral Form of FunctionalThe standard form with one state variable:$$V[y]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),y’(t)]dt$$ The standard form with two state variables:$$V[y,z]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),z(t),y’(t),z’(t)]dt$$ Other Forms of FunctionalRely exclusively on the terminal point with one state variable: Problem of Mayer: $$V[y]=G[T,y(T)]$$ Rely both on path values and the terminal point: Problem of Bolza: $$V[y]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),y’(t)]dt+G[T,y(T)]$$ Although the problem of Bolza may seem to be the more general formulation, the truth is that the three types of problems-standard, Mayer, and Bolza-are all convertible into one another. Rely exclusively on the terminal point with two state variables: Problem of Mayer with two state variables $$V[y,z]=G[T, y(T),z(T)]$$ Alternative Approaches to Dynamic OptimizationThe Calculus of Variations$$\begin{array}{lll} \mbox{Maximize or Minimize} &V[y]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),y’(t)]dt\ \ \mbox{subject to}& y(0)=A\ &(A\ \mbox{given})\ \ \mbox{and }&y(T)=Z\ &(T,Z\ \mbox{given})\end{array}$$ In order to make such problems meaningful, it is necessary that the functional be integrable (i.e., the integral must be convergent). Furthermore, we shall assume that all the functions that appear in the problem are continuous and continuously differentiable. This assumption is needed because the basic methodology underlying the calcu­lus of variations closely parallels that of the classical differential calculus. The main difference is that, instead of dealing with the differential $dx$ that changes the value of $y=f(x)$, we will now deal with the “variation” of an entire curve $y(t)$ that affects the value of the functional $V[y]$. Optimal Control Theory$$\begin{array}{lll} \mbox{Maximize or Minimize} &V[u]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),u(t)]dt\ \ \mbox{subject to}& y’(t)=f[t,y(t),u(t))]\ \ &y(0)=A\ &(A\ \mbox{given})\ \ \mbox{and }&y(T)=Z\ &(T,Z\ \mbox{given})\end{array}$$ Additional constraint:$$u(t)\in\mathscr{U}\mbox{ for }0\leq t\leq T$$ Aside from the time variable $t$ and the state variable $y(t)$, consideration is given to a control variable $u(t)$. Indeed, it is the latter type of variable that gives optimal control theory its name and occupies the center of stage in this new approach to dynamic optimiza­tion. To focus attention on the control variable implies that the state variable is relegated to a secondary status. This would be acceptable only if the decision on a control path $u(t)$ will, once given an initial condition on $y$, unambiguously determine a state-variable path $y(t)$ as a by-product. For this reason, an optimal control problem must contain an equation that relates $y$ to $u$:$$y’(t)=f[t,y(t),u(t))]$$ Such an equation, called an equation of motion (or transition equation or state equation), shows how, at any moment of time, given the value of the state variable, the planner’s choice of $u$ will drive the state variable y over time. Once we have found the optimal control-variable path $u^*(t)$, the equation of motion would make it possible to construct the related optimal state-variable path $y^*(t)$. Dynamic Programming:The most important distinguishing characteristics of this approach are two: First, it embeds the given control problem in a family of control problems, with the consequence that in solving the given problem, we are actually solving the entire family of problems. Second, for each member of this family of problems, primary attention is focused on the optimal value of the functional, $V^*$, rather than on the properties of the optimal state path $y^*(t)$ (as in the calculus of variations) or the optimal control path $u^*(t)$ (as in optimal control theory). Referring to Fig. 1.6 (adapted from Fig. 1.1), given the original problem of finding the least-cost path from point $A$ to point $Z$, we consider the larger problem of finding the least-cost path from each point in the set ${A, B, C, . . . , Z}$ to the terminal point $Z$. Since every component problem has a unique optimal path value, it is possible to write an optimal value function$$V^* = V^*(i)\ \ \ \ ( i = A, B, .. . , Z)$$ which says that we can determine an optimal path value for every possible initial point. From this, we can also construct an optimal policy function, which will tell us how best to proceed from any specific initial point $i$, in order to attain $V^*(i)$ by the proper selection of a sequence of arcs leading from point $i$ to the terminal point $Z$. Returning to Fig. 1.6, imagine that our immediate problem is merely that of determining the optimal values for stage 5, associated with the three initial points $I$, $J$, and $K$. The answer is easily seen to be$$V^*(I) = 3,\ V^*(J) = 1,\ V^*(K) =2\tag{1.10}$$ Having found the optimal values for $I$, $J$, and $K$, the task of finding the least-cost values $V^*(G)$ and $V^*(H)$ becomes easier. Moving back to stage 4 and utilizing the previously obtained optimal-value information in (1.10), we can determine $V^*(G)$ as well as the optimal path $GZ$ (from $G$ to $Z$) as follows: $$\begin{array}{} V^*(G)&= \min{\mbox{value of arc }GI + V^*(I),\mbox{ value of arc }GJ + V^*(J)}\&=\min{2+ 3,8+1}=5 \mbox{ [The optimal path GZ is GIZ.]}\end{array}\tag{1.11}$$ By the same token, we find$$\begin{array}{} V^*(H)&= \min{\mbox{value of arc }HJ + V^*(J),\mbox{ value of arc }HK + V^*(K)}\&=\min{4+ 1,6+2}=5 \mbox{ [The optimal path HZ is HJZ.]}\end{array}\tag{1.12}$$ With the knowledge of $V^*(G)$ and $V^*(H)$, we can then move back one more stage to calculate $V^*(D), V^*(E)$, and $V^*(F)$-and the optimal paths $DZ, EZ$, and $FZ$-in a similar manner. And, with two more such steps, we will be back to stage 1, where we can determine $V^*(A)$ and the optimal path $AZ$, that is, solve the original given problem. The essence of the iterative solution procedure is captured in Bellman’s principle of optimality, which states, roughly, that if you chop off the first arc from an optimal sequence of arcs, the remaining abridged sequence must still be optimal in its own right-as an optimal path from its own initial point to the terminal point. If $EHJZ$ is the optimal path from $E$ to $Z$, for example, then $HJZ$ must be the optimal path from $H$ to $Z$. Conversely, if $HJZ$ is already known to be the optimal path from $H$ to $Z$, then a longer optimal path that passes through $H$ must use the sequence $HJZ$ at the tail end. This reasoning is behind the calculations in (1.11) and (1.12). But note that in order to apply the principle of optimality and the iterative procedure to delineate the optimal path from $A$ to $Z$, we must find the optimal value associated with every possible point in Fig. 1.6. This explains why we must embed the original problem. Even though the essence of dynamic programming is sufficiently clari­fied by the discrete example in Fig. 1.6, the full version of dynamic program­ ming includes the continuous-time case. Unfortunately, the solution of continuous-time problems of dynamic programming involves the more ad­vanced mathematical topic of partial differential equations. Besides, partial differential equations often do not yield analytical solutions. Reference Alpha C. Chiang, 1992, “Elements of Dynamic Optimization”;

posts.title: The Fundamental Problem of the Calculus of Variations
posts.text: The Fundamental Problem$$\begin{array}{lll} \mbox{Maximize or Minimize} &V[y]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),y’(t)]dt\ \ \mbox{subject to}& y(0)=A\ &(A\ \mbox{given})\ \ \mbox{and }&y(T)=Z\ &(T,Z\ \mbox{given})\end{array}\tag{2.1}$$ The maximization and minimization problems differ from each other in the second-order conditions, but they share the same first-order conditions. The task of variational calculus is to select from a set of admissible $y$ paths (or trajectories) the one that yields an extreme value of $V[y]$. Since the calculus of variations is based on the classical methods of calculus, requiring the use of first and second derivatives, we shall restrict the set of admissible paths to those continuous curves with continuous derivatives. A smooth $y$ path that yields an extremum of $V[y]$ is called an extremal. We shall also assume that the integrand function $F$ is twice differentiable. The Euler EquationDifferentiating a Definite Integral Considering the definite integral$$I(x)\equiv \int^b_aF(t,x)dt$$ We have the Leibnniz’s Rule $$\frac{dI}{dx}=\int^b_aF_x(t,x)dt$$ Considering another definite integral$$K(x)\equiv\int^{b(x)}_{a(x)}F(t,x)dt$$ We have $$\frac{dK}{dx}=\int^{b(x)}_{a(x)}F_x(t,x)dt+F[b(x),x]b’(x)-F[a(x),x]a’(x)$$ Development of the Euler EquationWith reference to Fig. 2.1, let the solid path $y^*(t)$ be a known extremal. We seek to find some property of the extremal that is absent in the (nonextremal) neighboring paths. Such a property would constitute a necessary condition for an extremal. To do this, we need for comparison purposes a family of neighboring paths which, by specification in (2.1), must pass through the given endpoints $(0, A)$ and $(T, Z)$. A simple way of generating such neighboring paths is by using a perturbing curve, chosen arbitrarily except for the restrictions that it be smooth and pass through the points $0$ and $T$ on the horizontal axis in Fig. 2.1. Consider a perturbing curve:$$p(0)=p(T)=0\tag{2.2}$$Using the perturbing curve, we can generate neighboring paths of the extremal $y^*(t)$:$$\begin{matrix} y(t)=y^{}(t)+\epsilon p(t) & \mbox{ [implying}& y’(t)={y^}’(t)+\epsilon p’(t)] \end{matrix}\tag{2.3}$$ Instead of considering $V$ as a functional of $y$ path, now consider it as a function of the variable $\epsilon$ $$V(\epsilon)=\int^T_0 F[y, y^{}(t)+\epsilon p(t), {y^}’(t)+\epsilon p’(t)]dt\tag{2.12}$$ The necessary condition for the extremal is:$$\frac{dV}{d\epsilon}\bigg\vert_{\epsilon=0}=0\tag{2.4}$$ Then we have$$\begin{aligned} \frac{dV}{d\epsilon}&=\int^T_0\frac{\partial F}{\partial \epsilon}dt=\int^T_0\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{d\epsilon}+\frac{\partial F}{\partial y'}\frac{dy'}{d\epsilon}\right)dt\\ &=\int^T_0[F_yp(t)+F_{y'}p'(t)]dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.13} $$ Breaking the integral into two parts$$\int^T_0 F_yp(t)dt+\int^T_0F_{y’}p’(t)dt=0\tag{2.14}$$ While this form of necessary condition is already free of the arbitrary variable $\epsilon$, the arbitrary perturbing curve $p(t)$ is still present along with its derivative $p’(t)$. To make the necessary condition fully operational, we must also eliminate $p(t)$ and $p’(t)$. Integration by parts$$\begin{aligned} \int^T_0F_{y'}p'(t)dt&=[F_{y'}p(t)]^T_0-\int^T_0 p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}dt\\ &=-\int^T_0p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.16} $$ Another version of necessary condition for the extremal:$$\int^T_0 p(t)\left[F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}\right]dt=0\tag{2.17}$$ Precisely because $p(t)$ enters in an arbitrary way, we may conclude that the condition $(2.17)$ can only be satisfied only if the bracketed expression is made to vanish for every value of $t$ on the extremal. Consequently, it is a necessary condition for an extremal that$$F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.18}$$ Break the second-order derivative into three parts:$$ \frac{dF_{y'}}{dt}=\frac{\partial F_{y'}}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial F_{y'}}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dt}+\frac{\partial F_{y'}}{\partial y'}\frac{dy'}{dt}=F_{ty'}+F_{yy'}y'(t)+F_{y'y'}y''(t) $$ We get the expanded version of Euler Equation:$$F_{y’y’}y’’(t)+F_{yy’}y’(t)+F_{ty’}-F_y=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.19}$$ The Euler equation is in general a second-order nonlinear differential equation. Its general solution will thus contain two arbitrary constants. Since our problem in (2.1) comes with two boundary conditions (one initial and one terminal), we should normally possess sufficient information to definitize the two arbitrary constants and obtain the definite solution. Some Special CasesSpecial Case I: $F=F(t,y’)$$$F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.18}$$ In this special case, the $F$ function is free of $y$, implying that $F_y=0$. Hence the Euler equation reduces to $\frac{dF_{y’}}{dt}=0$, Hence the solution is$$F_{y'}=\mbox{constant}\tag{2.20} $$ Special Case II: $F=F(y,y’)$$$F_{y’y’}y’’(t)+F_{yy’}y’(t)+F_{ty’}-F_y=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.19}$$ Since $F$ is free of $t$ in this case, we have $F_{ty’}=0$, so the Euler equations reduces to$$ F_{y’y’}y’’(t)+F_{yy’}y’(t)-F_y=0$$ Note that$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dt}(y'F_{y'}-F)&=\frac{d}{dt}(y'F_{y'})-\frac{d}{dt}F(y,y')\\ &=F_{y'}{y''}+y'(F_{yy'}y'+F_{y'y'}y'')-(F_yy'+F_{y'}y'')\\ &=y'(F_{y'y'}y''+F_{yy'}y'-F_y) \end{aligned} $$ So the Euler equation can be written as $\frac{d}{dt}(y’F_{y’}-F)=0$, which means$$F-y’F_{y’}=\mbox{constant}\tag{2.21}$$ Special Case III: $F=F(y’)$$$F_{y’y’}y’’(t)+F_{yy’}y’(t)+F_{ty’}-F_y=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.19}$$ When $F$ depends on $y’$ alone, $F_{yy’}=F_{ty’}=F_y=0$. And the Euler equation reduces to$$ F_{y'y'}y''(t)=0\tag{2.24} $$ If $y’’(t)=0$, then $y’(t)=c_1$ and $y(t)=c_1t+c_2$. If $F_{y’y’}=0$, then since $F_{y’y’}$ is, like $F$ itself, a function of $y’$ alone, the solution of $F_{y’y’}=0$ should appear as specific values pf $y’$. Suppose there are one or more real solutions $y’=k_i$, then we can deduce that $y=k_it+c$, which again represents a family of straight lines. Consequently, given an integrand function that depends on $y’$ alone, we can always take its extermal to be a straight line. Special Case IV: $F=F(t,y)$$$F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.18}$$ Since $y’$ is missing from the $F$ function, we have $F_{y’}=0$, the Euler equation reduces to$$ F_y(t,y)=0 $$ The fact that the derivative $y’$ does not appear in this equation means that the Euler equation is not a differential equation. Since there are no arbitrary constraints in its solution to be definitized in accordance with the given boundary conditions, the extremal may not satisfy the boundary conditions except by sheer coincidence. Thus, $F(t,y)$ is, in a special sense, “linear” in $y’$. Two generalizations of the Euler EuqationThe Case of Several State VariablesThe objective functional with $n>1$ state variables$$V[y_1,…,y_n]=\int^T_0 F(t,y_1,…,y_n,y_1’,…,y_n’)dt\tag{2.26}$$ Then we have$$F_{y_j}-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’_j}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.27}$$ When $n=2$, we have$$\begin{aligned} F_{y'y'}y''(t)+F_{z'y'}z''(t)+F_{yy'}y'(t)+F_{zy'}z'(t)+F_{ty'}-F_y=0\\ F_{y'z'}y''(t)+F_{z'z'}z''(t)+F_{yz'}y'(t)+F_{zz'}z'(t)+F_{tz'}-F_z=0\\& \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T] \end{aligned}\tag{2.28} $$ The Case of Higher-Order DerivativesThe objective functional contains high-order derivatives$$V[y]=\int^T_0 F(t,y,y’’,…,y^{(n)})dt\tag{2.29}$$ Then we have$$F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}+\frac{d^2}{dt^2}F_{y’}-\cdots+(-1)^n\frac{d^n}{dt^n}F_{y^{(n)}}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler-Poisson Equation]} \tag{2.30}$$ Reference Alpha C. Chiang, 1992, “Elements of Dynamic Optimization”;

posts.title: Transversality Conditions for Variable-Endpoint Problems
posts.text: The General Transversality ConditionThe Variable-Terminal-Point Problem$$\begin{array}{lll} \mbox{Maximize or Minimize} &V[y]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),y’(t)]dt\ \ \mbox{subject to}& y(0)=A\ &(A\ \mbox{given})\ \ \mbox{and }&y(T)=y_T\ &(T,y_T\ \mbox{free})\end{array}\tag{3.1}$$ Using the variable $\epsilon$ to express any value of $T$ in the neighborhood of $T^*$.$$ T=T^*+\epsilon\Delta T\tag{3.2} $$ Consider $T$ as a function of $\epsilon$, with derivative:$$ \frac{dT}{d\epsilon}=\Delta T\tag{3.3} $$ Generating neighboring paths of the extremal $y^*(t)$ with the same $\epsilon$$$\begin{matrix} y(t)=y^{*}(t)+\epsilon p(t) & \mbox{ [implying}& y'(t)={y^*}'(t)+\epsilon p'(t)] \end{matrix}\tag{3.4} $$ However, although the $p(t)$ curve must still satisfy the condition $p(0) = 0$, to force the neighboring paths to pass through the fixed·initial point, the other condition-$p(T)= 0$-should now be dropped, because $Y_T$ is free. Consider $V$ as a function of the variable $\epsilon$, the upper limit of integration in the $V$ function will also vary with $\epsilon$$$V(\epsilon)=\int^{T(\epsilon)}_0 F[y, y^{}(t)+\epsilon p(t), {y^}’(t)+\epsilon p’(t)]dt\tag{3.5}$$ Deriving the General Transversality ConditionThe necessary condition:$$\frac{dV}{d\epsilon}=\int^{T(\epsilon)}_0\frac{\partial F}{\partial \epsilon}dt+F[T,y(T),y’(T)]\frac{dT}{d\epsilon}=0\tag{3.6}$$ Recalling previous equations$$ \begin{aligned} \int^{T}_0\frac{\partial F}{\partial \epsilon}dt&=\int^{T}_0\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{d\epsilon}+\frac{\partial F}{\partial y'}\frac{dy'}{d\epsilon}\right)dt\\ &=\int^{T}_0[F_yp(t)+F_{y'}p'(t)]dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.13} $$ Breaking the integral into two parts$$\int^{T}0 F_yp(t)dt+\int^{T}_0F{y’}p’(t)dt=0\tag{2.14}$$ Integration by parts$$ \begin{aligned} \int^{T}_0F_{y'}p'(t)dt&=[F_{y'}p(t)]^{T}_0-\int^{T}_0 p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}dt\\ &=[F_{y'}]_{t={T}}p(T)-\int^{T}_0p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.16'} $$ Thus we have$$\mbox{First term in } (3.6)=\int^{T}0p(t)\left[F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}\right]dt+[F{y’}]_{t={T}}p(T)$$ According to (3.3) we also have$$\mbox{Second term in } (3.6)=[F]_{t=T}\Delta T$$ Then we can transform (3.6)​ into$$ \int^{T}_0p(t)\left[F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}\right]dt+[F_{y'}]_{t={T}}p(T)+[F]_{t=T}\Delta T =0\tag{3.7} $$ Of the three terms on the left-hand side of $(3. 7)$, each contains its own independent arbitrary element: $p(t)$ (the entire perturbing curve) in the first term $p(T)$ (the terminal value on the perturbing curve) in the second term $\Delta T$ (the arbitrarily chosen change in $T$) in the third term Thus we cannot presume any offsetting or cancellation of terms. Consequently, in order to satisfy the condition (3. 7)​, each of the three terms must individually be set equal to zero. When the first term in (3.7)​ is set equal to zero, the Euler equation emerges.$$F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.18}$$ This establish the fact that the Euler equation remains valid as a necessary condition in the variable-endpoint problem. Getting rid of the arbitrary quantity $p(T)$ by transforming it into terms of $\Delta T$ and $\Delta y_T$$$\Delta y(T)=p(T)+y’(T)\Delta T$$ This can be done with the help of Fig. 3.1. Rearranging it and get$$ p(T)=\Delta y_T-y'(T)\Delta T\tag{3.8} $$ The result in (3.8)​ is build on condition that $\epsilon=1$ while deriving, but it is still valid if $\epsilon$ is not set equal to one. Eliminating $p(T)$ in (3.7)​, and dropping the first term in ​(3.7)​, we get another necessary condition$$ \begin{aligned} {[F_{y'}]}_{t={T}}p(T)+[F]_{t=T}\Delta T&=[F_{y'}]_{t={T}}[\Delta y_T-y'(T)\Delta T]+[F]_{t=T}\Delta T \\ &=[F_{y'}]_{t=T}\Delta y_{T}+[F-y'F_{y'}]_{t=T}\Delta T \end{aligned} $$ Rearranging it and get$$[F-y’F_{y’}]{t=T}\Delta T+[F{y’}]{t=T}\Delta y{T}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [General Transversality Condition]}\tag{3.9}$$ This condition, unlike the Euler equation, is relevant only to one point of time, $T$. Its role is to take the place of the missing terminal condition in the present problem. Specialized Transversality ConditionsDepending on the exact specification of the terminal line or curve, however, the general condition (3.9) can be written in various specialized forms. Vertical Terminal LineFor a fixed $T$, $\Delta T=0$, so we only need$$[F_{y’}]_{t=T}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Transversality Condition for Vertical Terminal Line]}\tag{3.10}$$ Horizontal Terminal LineFor a fixed $y_T$, $\Delta y_T=0$, so we only need$$[F-y’F_{y’}]_{t=T}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Transversality Condition for Hoizontal Terminal Line]}\tag{3.11}$$ Terminal CurveWith a terminal curve $y_T=\phi(T)$, we also have $\Delta y_T=\phi’\Delta T$. Transform (3.9)​, we have$$[F-y’F_{y’}+F_{y’}\phi’]_{t=T}\Delta T=0$$ For an arbitrary $\Delta T$, we have $$[F-y’F_{y’}+F_{y’}\phi’]_{t=T}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Transversality Condition for Terminal Curve]}\tag{3.12}$$ Truncated Vertical Terminal LineThe usual case ofvertical terminal line, with $\Delta T =0$, specializes (3.9) to$$[F_{y’}]{t=T}\Delta{y_T}=0$$ When the line is truncated-restricted by the terminal condition $y_T>y_{\min}$ where $y_{\min}$ is a minimum permissible level of $y$ the optimal solution can have two possible types of outcome: $y_T^*>y_{\min}$ or $y_T^*=y_{\min}$ For $y_T^*>y_{\min}$, the constraint is not binding, we have$$[F_{y’}]{t=T}=0\ \ \ for\ \ \ y_T^*>y_{\min}\tag{3.14}$$For $y_T^*=y_{min}$, the constraint is binding, with Kuhn-Tucker condition, we have$$[F{y’}]{t=T}\leq0\ \ \ for\ \ \ y_T^*=y_{min}\tag{3.16}$$Combing (3.14)​ and (3.16)​ we have$$[F{y’}]{t=T}\leq0\ \ \ for\ \ \ y_T^\geq y_{min}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ (y_T^-y_{min})[F{y’}]_{t=T}=0\ \ \ \mbox{ [Transversality Condition for Truncated Vertical Terminal Line in the Maximization Problem]}\tag{3.17}$$ $$[F_{y’}]{t=T}\geq0\ \ \ for\ \ \ y_T^\geq y_{min}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ (y_T^-y_{min})[F{y’}]_{t=T}=0\ \ \ \mbox{[Transversality Condition for Truncated Vertical Terminal Line in the Minimization Problem]}\tag{3.18}$$ Three GeneralizationsThe Case of Several State Variables$$\left[F-(y_1’F_{y_1’}+\cdots+y_n’F_{y_n’})\right]{t=T}\Delta T+\left[F{y_1’}\right]{t=T}\Delta{y_{1T}}+\cdots+\left[F_{y_n’}\right]{t=T}\Delta y{nT}=0\ \ \ \mbox{[The General (Terminal) Transversality Condition]}\tag{3.27}$$ When $n=2$$$\left[F-(y’F_{y’}+z’F_{z’})\right]{t=T}\Delta T+\left[F{y’}\right]{t=T}\Delta{y_{T}}+\left[F_{z’}\right]{t=T}\Delta z{T}=0\tag{3.27’}$$ The Case of Higher DerivativesThe general transversality condition for the case of $F(t,y’,y’’,y’’’)$ is$$\begin{aligned} &\left[F-y’F_{y’}-y’’F_{y’’}+y’\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’’}\right]{t=T}\Delta T\&+\left[F{y’}-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’’}\right]{t=T}\Delta y_T+[F_{y’’}]{t=T}\Delta y’_{T}=0 \end{aligned}\tag{3.28}$$ Reference Alpha C. Chiang, 1992, “Elements of Dynamic Optimization”;

posts.title: Second-Order Conditions
posts.text: Second-Order ConditionsSecond-Order Necessary Conditions$$\frac{d^2 V}{d\epsilon ^2}\leq 0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{for maximization of } V]$$ $$\frac{d^2 V}{d\epsilon ^2}\geq 0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{for minimization of } V]$$ Second-Order Sufficient Conditions$$\frac{d^2 V}{d\epsilon ^2}< 0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{for maximization of } V]$$ $$\frac{d^2 V}{d\epsilon ^2}> 0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{for minimization of } V]$$ The Second Derivative of $V$Recalling the first derivative of $V$$$\begin{aligned} \frac{dV}{d\epsilon}&=\int^T_0\frac{\partial F}{\partial \epsilon}dt=\int^T_0\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{d\epsilon}+\frac{\partial F}{\partial y’}\frac{dy’}{d\epsilon}\right)dt\ &=\int^T_0[F_yp(t)+F_{y’}p’(t)]dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.13}$$ Since all the partial derivatives of $F(t, y, y’)$ are, like $F$ itself, functions of $t$, $y$, and $y’$ And recalling$$\begin{matrix} y(t)=y^{*}(t)+\epsilon p(t) & \ & y'(t)={y^*}'(t)+\epsilon p'(t) \end{matrix}\tag{2.3} $$ So $y$ and $y’$ are, in turn, both functions of $\epsilon$, with derivatives$$ \frac{dy}{d\epsilon}=p(t)\ \ \ \ and\ \ \ \ \ \ \frac{dy'}{d\epsilon}=p'(t)\tag{4.1} $$ Thus we have$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{d^2V}{d\epsilon^2}&=\frac{d}{d\epsilon}\left(\frac{dV}{d\epsilon}\right)=\frac{d}{d\epsilon}\int^T_0[F_yp(t)]+F_{y'}p'(t)]dt \\&=\int^T_0\left[p(t)\frac{d}{d\epsilon}F_y+p'(t)\frac{d}{d\epsilon}F_{y'}\right]dt \end{aligned}\tag{4.2} $$ In view of fact that $$\frac{d}{d\epsilon}F_y=F_{yy}\frac{dy}{d\epsilon}+F_{yy’}\frac{dy’}{d\epsilon}=F_{yy}p(t)+F_{y’y}p’(t)$$ and similarly$$ \frac{d}{d\epsilon}F_{y'}=F_{yy'}p(t)+F_{y'y'}p'(t) $$ The second derivative (4.2)​ can be simplified as$$ \frac{d^2V}{d\epsilon^2}=\int^T_0\left[F_{yy}p^2(t)+2F_{yy'}p(t)p'(t)+F_{y'y'}{p'}^2(t)\right]dt\tag{4.2'} $$ The Quadratic-Form TestThe second derivative in (4.2’)​ is a definite integral with a quadratic form as its integrand. Since $t$ spans the interval $[0, T ]$, we have, of course, not one, but an infinite number of quadratic forms in the integral. Nevertheless, if it can be established that the quadratic form-with $F_{yy’}$, $F_{yy’}$, and $F_{y’y’}$ evaluated on the extremal-is negative definite for every $t$, then $\frac{d^2V}{d\epsilon^2} < 0$, and the extremal maximizes $V$. Similarly, positive definiteness of the quadratic form for every $t$ is sufficient for minimization of $V$. Even if we can only establish sign semidefiniteness, we can at least have the second-order necessary conditions checked. For some reason, however, the quadratic-form test was totally ignored in the historical development of the classical calculus of variations. In a more recent development, however, the concavity / convexity of the integrand function $F$ is used in a sufficient condition. While concavity / convexity does not per se require differentiability, it is true that if the $F$ function does possess continuous second derivatives, then its concavity / convexity can be checked by means of the sign semidefiniteness of the second-order total differential of $F$. So the quadratic-form test definitely has a role to play in the calculus of variations. The Concavity / Convexity Sufficient ConditionA Sufficiency Theorem for Fixed-Endpoint Problems$$\begin{array}{lll} \mbox{Maximize or Minimize} &V[y]=\int^T_0 F[t,y(t),y’(t)]dt\ \ \mbox{subject to}& y(0)=A\ &(A\ \mbox{given})\ \ \mbox{and }&y(T)=Z\ &(T,Z\ \mbox{given})\end{array}\tag{2.1}$$ Just as a concave / convex objective function in a static optimization prob­ lem is sufficient to identify an extremum as an absolute maximum / mini­mum, a similar sufficiency theorem holds in the calculus of variations:$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{For the fixed-endpoint problem } (2.1), \mbox{if the integrand function}\ F(t,y,y’)\ \mbox{is concave} \&\mbox{in the variables}\ (y,y’), \mbox{then the Euler equation is sufficient for an absolute}\&\mbox{maximum of}\ V[y].\mbox{ Similarly, if}\ F(t, y, y’)\ \mbox{is convex in}\ (y, y’), \mbox{then the Euler}\& \mbox{equation is sufficient for an absolute minimum of}\ V[y]. \end{aligned}\tag{4.3}$$ It should be pointed out that concavity / convexity in $(y,y’)$ means concavity / convexity in the two variables $y$ and $y’$ jointly, not in each variable separately. The proof of this theorem for the concave case.$$\begin{aligned} F(t,y,y’)-F(t,y^*,{y^*}’)&\leq F_y(t,y^*,{y^*}’) (y-y^*)+F_{y’}(t,y^*,{y^*}’)(y’-{y^*}’)\ &= F_y(t,y^*,{y^*}’)\epsilon p(t)+F_{y’}(t,y^*,{y^*})’\epsilon p’(t) \end{aligned}\tag{4.4}$$ Recalling that$$ \begin{aligned} \int^T_0F_{y'}p'(t)dt&=[F_{y'}p(t)]^T_0-\int^T_0 p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}dt\\ &=-\int^T_0p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.16} $$ And the Euler Equation$$ F_y-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T] $$ Integrate both sides of (4.4) with respect to $t$ over the interval $[0,T]$$$ \begin{aligned} V[y]-V[y^*]&\leq \epsilon\int^T_0\left[F_y(t,y^*,{y^*}')p(t)+F_{y'}(t,y^*,{y^*}')p'(t)\right]dt\\ &=\epsilon \int^T_0 p(t)\left[F_y(t,y^*,{y^*}')-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}(t,y^*,{y^*}')\right]dt\\ &=0 \end{aligned}\tag{4.5} $$ The first equation follows from (2.16)​, the last equation follows from the fact that $y^*(t)$ satisfies the Euler Equation ​(2.18)​ Note that if the $F$ function is strictly concave in $(y, y’)$, then the weak inequality $\leq$ in (4.4)​ and (4.5)​ will become the strict inequality $<$. The result, $V[y] < V[y^*]$, will then establish $V[y^*]$ to be a unique absolute maximum of $V$. By the same token, a strictly convex $F$ will make $V[y^*]$ a unique absolute minimum. Generalization to Variable Terminal PointRecalling$$\begin{aligned} \int^{T}0F{y’}p’(t)dt&=[F_{y’}p(t)]^{T}0-\int^{T}0 p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F{y’}dt\ &=[F{y’}]_{t={T}} p(T)-\int^{T}0p(t)\frac{d}{dt}F{y’}dt \end{aligned}\tag{2.16’}$$ Thus the Equation (4.5)​ becomes$$\begin{aligned} V[y]-V[y^*]&\leq \epsilon\int^T_0\left[F_y(t,y^*,{y^*}')p(t)+F_{y'}(t,y^*,{y^*}')p'(t)\right]dt\\ &=\epsilon \int^T_0 p(t)\left[F_y(t,y^*,{y^*}')-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y'}(t,y^*,{y^*}')\right]dt+\epsilon[F_{y'}p(t)]_{t={T}}\\ &=\epsilon[F_{y'}p(t)]_{t={T}} \\ &=[F_{y'}(y-y^*)]_{t={T}} \end{aligned}\tag{4.5'} $$ To ensure the maximum, $F(t, y, y’)$ in (4.3)​ only needs to be supplemented in the present case by a nonpositivity condition on the expression $[F_{y’}(y-y^*)]_{t={T}}$. But this supplementary condition is automatically met when the transversality condition is satisfied for the vertical-terminal-line problem, namely, $[F_{y’}]=0$. As for the truncated case, the transversality condition calls for either $[F_{y’}]=0$ (when the minimum acceptable terminal value is nobinding), or $y^*=y_{\min}$ (when that terminal value is binding), thereby in effect turning the problem into one with a fixed terminal point). Either way, the supplementary condition is met. Thus, if the integrand function $F$ is concave / convex in the variables $(y,y’)$ in a problem with a vertical terminal lime or truncated vertical terminal line, then the Euler equation plus the transversality condition are sufficient for an absolute maximum / minimum of $V[y]$. Reference Alpha C. Chiang, 1992, “Elements of Dynamic Optimization”;

posts.title: Infinite Planning Horizon
posts.text: Methodological Issues of Inifinite Horizon​ The convergence problem arises because the objective functional, now in the form of $\int^\infty_0F(t, y, y’)dt$, is an improper integral which may or may not have a finite value. In the case where the integral diverges, there may exist more than one $y(t)$ path that yields an infinite value for the objective functional and it would be difficult to determine which among these paths is optimal. There are several certain conditions that are sufficient for convergence. Condition IGiven the improper integral $\int^\infty_0F(t, y, y’) dt$, if the integrand $F$ is finite throughout the interval of integration, and if $F$ attains a zero value at some finite point of time, say, $t_0$, and remains at zero for all $t > t_0$, then the integral will converge. Although the integral nominally has an infinite horizon, the effective upper limit of integration is a finite value, $t_0$. Thus, the given improper integral reduces in effect to a proper one, with assurance that it will integrate to a finite value. Condition IIIIn the integral $\int^\infty_0F(t,y,y’)dt$, if the integrand takes the form of $G(t,y,y’)e^{-\rho t}$, where $\rho$ is a positive rate of discount, and the $G$ function is bounded, then the integral will converge. A distinguishing feature of this integral is the presence of the discount factor $e^{\rho t}$ which, ceteris paribus, provides a dynamic force to drive the integrand down toward zero over time at a good speed. When the $G(t,y,y’)$ component of the integrand is positive (as in most economic applications) and has an upper hound, say, $\hat{G}$, then the downward force of $e^\rho t$ is sufficient to make the integral converge. More formally, since the value of the $G$ function can never exceed the value of the constant $\hat{G}$, we can write$$ \int^\infty_0G(t,y,y')e^{-\rho t}dt\leq\int^\infty_0\hat{G}e^{-\rho t}dt=\frac{\hat{G}}{\rho}\tag{5.3} $$ It follows that the first integral must also be convergent. The Matter of Transversality ConditionsWhen the planning horizon is infinite, there is no longer a specific terminal $T$ value for us to adhere to. And the terminal state may also be left open. Thus transversality conditions are needed. Recalling$$[F-y’F_{y’}]{t=T}\Delta T+[F{y’}]{t=T}\Delta y{T}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [General Transversality Condition]}\tag{3.9}$$ In the present context, $(3.9)$ must be modified to$$ [F-y'F_{y'}]_{t\to \infty}\Delta T+[F_{y'}]_{t\to \infty}\Delta y_{T}=0\tag{5.4} $$ where each of the two terms must individually vanish. Since there is no fixed $T$ in the present context, $\Delta T$ is perforce nonzero, and this necessitates the condition$$\lim_{t\to \infty}(F-y’F_{y’})=0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{Transversalilty Condition for the Infinite Horizon}]\tag{5.5}$$ As to the second term in $(5.4)$, if an asymptotic terminal state is specified in the problem:$$\lim_{t\to \infty}y(t)=y_{\infty}=\mbox{a given constant}\tag{5.6}$$ then the second term in $(5.4)$ will vanish on its own $(\Delta y_T = 0)$ and no transversality condition is needed. But if the terminal state is free, then we should impose the additional condition$$\lim_{t\to\infty} F_{y’}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{Transversalilty Condition for Free Terminal State}]\tag{5.7}$$ The Optimal Social Saving BehaviorThe Ramsey ModelThe central question addressed by Ramsey is that of intertemporal resource allocation: How much of the national output at any point of time should be for current consumption to yield current utility, and how much should be saved (and invested) so as to enhance future production and consumption, and hence yield future utility? $$\mbox{Maximize}\ \int^\infty_0[U(C)-D(L)]dt\tag{5.26}$$ where$$ C=Q(K,L)-K'\tag{5.25} $$ since we assuming away depreciation.$$Q(K,L)=C+S=C+K’$$ This implies the output can be consumed or saved, but what is saved always results in investment and capital accumulation. Utility function $U(C)$ has nonincreasing marginal utility, $U’’(C)\leq 0$ In order to produce its consumption goods, society incurs disutility of labor $D(L)$, with nondecreasing marginal utility, $D’’(L)\geq 0$ The Question of ConvergenceThe absence of discount factor unfortunately forfeits the opportunity to take advantage of Condition III to establish convergence, even if the integrand has an upper bound. Thus replace (5.26)​ with the following substitute problem: $$\begin{array}{lll} \mbox{Minimize} &\int^\infty_0[B-U(C)+D(L)]dt\ \ \mbox{subject to} &K(0)=K_0&(K_0)\ \mbox{given} \end{array}\tag{5.26’}$$ where $B$ (for Bliss) is a postulated maximum attainable level of net utility. Condition I guarantees the convergence. The Solution of the ModelFrom (5.26’)​ we get$$F=B-U(C)+D(L)\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{where}\ C=Q(K,L)-K’$$ The derivative with respect to $L$ and $L’$:$$\begin{aligned} &F_L=-U'(C)\frac{\partial C}{\partial L}+D'(L)\equiv-\mu Q_L+D'(L)\\ &F_{L'}=0 \end{aligned} $$ The derivative with respect to $K$ and $K’$:$$ \begin{aligned} &F_K=-U'(C)\frac{\partial C}{\partial K}\equiv-\mu Q_K\\ &F_{K'}=-U'(C)\frac{\partial C}{\partial K}=-U'(C)(-1)=\mu \end{aligned} $$ According to the Euler Equation$$F_{y_j}-\frac{d}{dt}F_{y’_j}=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all}\ t\in[0,T]\ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{ [Euler Equation]}\tag{2.27}$$ we have$$ \begin{aligned} &F_L-\frac{dF_{L'}}{dt}=0\\ &F_K-\frac{dF_{K'}}{dt}=0 \end{aligned} $$ which means$$ D'(L)=\mu Q_L\ \ \ \ \mbox{for all } t\geq0\tag{5.27} $$ $$\frac{d\mu/dt}{\mu}=-Q_K\ \ \ \ \mbox{for all } t\geq0\tag{5.28}$$ The marginal disutility of labor must, at each point of time, be equated to the product of the marginal utility of consumption and the marginal product of labor. The marginal utility of consumption, must at every point of time have a growth rate equal to the negative of the marginal product of capital. A Look at the Transversality Conditions$$\lim_{t\to \infty}(F-y’F_{y’})=0\ \ \ \ \ \ [\mbox{Transversalilty Condition for the Infinite Horizon}]\tag{5.5}$$ When it is applied to two state variables, then we have $$\lim_{t\to \infty}(F-L’F_{L’})=0\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ and\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \lim_{t\to \infty}(F-K’F_{K’})=0$$ In view of the fact that $F_{L’} = 0$, the first of these conditions reduces to the condition that $F\to 0$ as $t\to\infty$. This would mean the net utility $U(C) - D(L)$ must tend to Bliss. Note that, by itself, this condition still leaves the constant in (5.29)​ uncertain. However, the other condition will fix the constant at zero because $F - K’F_{K’}$ is nothing but the left-hand-side expression in (5.29)​. The present problem implicitly specifies the terminal state at Bliss. Consequently, the transversality condition (5.7) is not needed. The Optimal Investment and Capital PathsOf greater interest to us is the optimal $K$ path and the related investment (and savings) path $K’$. Instead of deducing these from the previous results, let us find this information by taking advantage of the fact that the present problem also falls under the Special Case II: $F=F(y,y’)$, which means $$F-K’F_{K’}=constant$$ or$$B-U(C)+D(L)-K’\mu=constant\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \mbox{for all } t\geq0\tag{5.29}$$ This equation can be solved for $K’$ as soon as the (arbitrary) constant on the right-hand side can be assigned a specific value. To find this value, we note that this constant is to hold for all $t$, including $t\to\infty$. We can thus make use of the fact that as $t\to\infty$, the economic objective of the model is to have $U(C) - D(L)$ tend to Bliss. As $t\to\infty$, $B-U(C)+D(L)\to0$, $\mu\to0$, then we have the arbitrary constant has to be $0$. Thus $$ {K^*}’=\frac{B-U(C)+D(L)}{\mu}\tag{5.30}$$ With the time argument explicitly written out,$${K^*}’(t)=\frac{B-U[C(t)]+D[L(t)]}{\mu(t)}\tag{5.30’}$$ This result is known as the Ramsey rule. It stipulates that, optimally, the rate of capital accumulation must at any point of time be equal to the ratio of the shortfall of net utility from Bliss to the marginal utility of consumption. From the Ramsey rule, it is possible to go one step further to find the $K^*(t)$ path by integrating (5.30’)​. For that, however, we need specific forms of $U(C)$ and $D(L)$ functions. The general solution of (5.30’)​ will contain one arbitrary constant, which can be definitized by the initial condition $K(0) = K_0$. And that would complete the solution of the model. The Concavity / Convexity Sufficient Condition AgainSufficient Conditions​ Recall that if the integrand function $F(t,y,y’)$ in a fixed-endpoint problem is concave / convex in the variables $(y, y’)$, then the Euler equation is sufficient for an absolute maximum / minimum of $V[y]$. Moreover, this sufficiency condition remains applicable when the terminal time is fixed but the terminal state is variable, provided that the supplementary condition$$ [F_{y'}(y-y^*)]_{t={T}}\leq 0 $$ is satisfied. For the infinite-horizon case, this supplementary becomes$$ \lim_{t\to \infty}[F_{y'}(y-y^*)]\leq 0\tag{5.44} $$ In this condition, $F_{y’}$ is to be evaluated along the optimal path, and $(y-y^*)$ represents the deviation of any admissible neighboring path $y(t)$ from the optimal path $y^*(t)$. Reference Alpha C. Chiang, 1992, “Elements of Dynamic Optimization”;
